Don't have Schizophrenia, but I do have auditory hallucinations. Especially on the days I'm tired. It mostly happens when I'm about to fall asleep. Nothing too creepy.   But one time, there was like decorative chime in my room, and I heard it fall which woke me up. When I looked at it, it was still hanging. Weirdest thing is, I never heard it fall for real, so how did my brain even know what sort of sound it would make when it fell? I didn't think too much of it at that time because hearing things was pretty common during that period. I've heard my name being said, the door handle being turned, horns of vehicles, screaming or just someone talking. Those were most common.
Personal story;   My aunt has schizophrenia to quite a severe degree. She once tried to stab me (this was before she had been diagnosed so she was fully unmedicated and deep in psychosis) she had been convinced that the devil was coming to steal my soul and the only way to save me was to send my soul to god.

I had a friend in high school who, as they would say, ‚Äúreally got the short end of the stick‚Äù. They had schizophrenia and Tourette‚Äôs that often fed on each other. They would often hallucinate an older man who would just stand or sit in the corner of the room and randomly scream at the most inopportune times. Whenever they saw him, their Tourette‚Äôs would cause them to start cursing at him and they would end up having a bad tic attack. Luckily through lots of therapy and medication, they were able to keep the hallucinations to a minimum, but their Tourette‚Äôs was always there. They usually just whistled and cleared their throat a lot. One day while we were hanging out they saw the old man and started cursing at him. I asked their dad what was the best way to help them and he said ‚Äúyou can try also yelling at the old man to go away, and if that doesn‚Äôt work, just hold their hand and keep telling them that you‚Äôre real.‚Äù So that‚Äôs what I did. We found that I was really good at getting the old man to leave if I shouted ‚Äúhey d****head! Get out!‚Äù Whenever that didn‚Äôt work, I‚Äôd do just what their dad had told me to do, and I‚Äôd sit there and hold their hand and keep reminding them that I‚Äôm real. Unfortunately, that friend and I didn‚Äôt stay in contact because of a big case of ‚Äúhe said/she said,‚Äù but I hope they‚Äôre doing good in their life.

I'm schizophrenic, and I understand that hallucinations and delusions are a big part of the disorder, but to be honest I dont have delusions and barely have hallucinations, but I have paranoia a lot of other symptoms and I just feel like I don't get represented a lot in the media, like when people talk about schizophrenia they always talk about those two symptoms, but you can be schizophrenic and don't really experience those, i was diagnosed with the disorder by several psychiatrist, but because of this I sometimes think "maybe I don't have it" Still thanks for making this video, and thanks for people who was featured in it, its really important to talk more about schizophrenia, a lot of people really unfamiliar with this disorder

I've taken a lot of psychedelics in my life, but I had a trip on some kind of drug once that I don't remember what it was, but it showed me just how vivid hallucinations can be. I was home alone and at one point my mom came in and we had a full conversation before she vanished like a wisp of smoke right in front of me. Some of the things I saw (lots of bugs) I know weren't real, but they were as clear as day. I talked to people that weren't there, experienced things that didn't happen and kept seeing weird, impossible looking animals all over my house. It would have been impossible to try to handle anything functional. Sometimes I wonder how close that experience was to a psychotic break.

Plus i probably dont have it but before my medication i uses to hallucinate every night to the point i would be afraid to move or let any of my body out of my bed or rather my blanket to the parts below my head in fear of being killed by the shadow that used to loom over me while i slept. I also saw manu things in my hallway that would chase me to my room at night. They would never come into my room because i thought they were afraid of the shadow that would watch me sleep, i called him the hat man. I also saw a slenderman looking guy who would watch me in my living room but would never do anything but stand still. My hallucinations would change every night besides those two. I would always be so scared, and now i have insomnia. I used to hear things sometimes, too, lol. But now, and even back then, i still have nightmares every night. I also would only have these at night. I still live in fear at night of seeing things, but I've been getting better.

I feel for folks with schizophrenia.  They have to work tremendously hard just to decipher what's real in an already stressful day.   Those that I've met with it, I've seen that they're someone others could learn the gift of patience from.  They're very strong with self control, as well... having been working through it since the hallucinations began.
I personally am not schizophrenic, but I do suffer from psychotic symptoms when under heavy stress. I had a psyche evaluation recently, not long after my brother had a break from reality and was actually diagnosed as schizophrenic. They've only diagnosed me with PTSD, but I have audiotory hallucinations when I'm triggered and/or under intense stress, where I start re-experiencing trauma of the past and i hear associated degrading phrases like someone is whispering or screaming them into my ears. When I'm in that stress induced state for too long, I start to see things as well and they've stayed pretty much the same over the years. I see a woman kinda like Cecilia does, she started out looking like sadako (the ring girl) and her face has always remained covered yet her gaze follows me, now her face is overshadowed by a big hood. Whenever i see her, dread and despair seem to envelop my whole body and i feel hopeless. I also see an abnormally tall man with a shadowy face but you always get the sense he's smiling sinisterly, he makes me feel super uneasy and paranoid. I thought i was schizophrenic for the longest time. I delved deep into psychology because i was convinced something was wrong with me. I remember watching Cecilias ted talk, and it made me cry the first time because i felt so haunted all the time and i felt like i was alone. I've told several people about my experiences, and they always act afraid of me afterwards which doesnt make much sense considering I'm the one dealing with the scary stuff. The thing that has always scared me is when i tell someone and they try to convince me I'm literaly seeing ghosts, that is a dangerous line of thinking and filled me with fear almost my whole childhood and can still make me anxious as an adult. Ive always tried to remain as closely footed in reality as possible while tackling hallucinations, paranoia, flashbacks, catatonic depression, and intense derealization... it's not always easy and i hate it when people are like "yeah but what if its real?" Like if i go too deep in that line of thinking i could end up in a really fearful and dark place, and the worst thing is the people that say these kinds of things have no idea what the impact of their words can have on people like me or my brother or anybody else that struggles with psychosis... It's not all sunshine and rainbows and we can't just shut it off, its hard work and sometimes that work is having to sort through the chaos of real and not real when everything around you feels like a nightmarish dream.
That 's so well done. It's a respectfull and honnest talk.

My mother is Schizophrenic, and I implore anyone who has this disorder to receive treatment. I know that Schizophrenics are not evil, but my experience with her was traumatic for my siblings and I, to the point where now, none of us speak to her. She refuses treatment, and has fallen into a torn reality that she has not come back from since 16 years ago. I respect Cecilia and Kody for speaking on their experiences and what they are going through everyday, and I hope that life is a little easier for them as they receive their treatment.

I am one of the first people that had a service dog for psychiatric reasons and I wonder if 1) those with schizophrenia are able to care for a service dog and 2) have they considered a service dog of so. One of the things I taught my dog to do is to help me differentiate if something is real or a hallucination (when overstressed I have them too).  The stuff I would hallucinate didn't belong in the current environment or circumstances. I taught my dog that when I'd say "oo, what is that". They would immediately survey the environment and if something out of place was present they would alert and fixate on it, if not they would look back at me expectantly so I knew that they found nothing. It really helps to be able to identify when something is real or not

Spending a day with individuals who have schizophrenia can be an eye-opening and empathetic experience. Dr. Tonmoy Sharma, a distinguished mental health specialist and author, in collaboration with Sovereign Health institution, utilizes a person-centered and holistic approach to support those with schizophrenia. Testimonies from both employees and patients emphasize the transformative impact of their services, underscoring the compassionate care and therapies provided. Dr. Tonmoy Sharma's advocacy further highlights the importance of understanding and supporting individuals with mental health conditions. Through evidence-based treatments, tailored to individual needs, and a commitment to reducing stigma, they work to help those in need lead more fulfilling lives while breaking down barriers surrounding schizophrenia and mental health in general.

I don‚Äôt have Schizophrenia itself, but I do have the closely related Major Depressive Disorder with Psychotic Elements (when you have psychotic symptoms closely tied to your mood symptoms of depression). My hallucinations often are auditory (usually picking apart every insecurity I have, it has at least given me very thick skin), though I do sometimes see scratchy visual hallucinations and on rare occasion I have realistic yet temporary events that are enough to convince me that something is happening that isn‚Äôt (usually in a grey area where I cannot risk ignoring it on the slim chance it‚Äôs real). Luckily, given that shortly before onset I got very interested in the condition, I learned how to recognise it and even see that it had happened before that research in a previous psych ward stay, so I actually managed to recognise it.

This is not an accurate picture of schizophrenia as a whole. There are other symptoms that are far worse than the severity of most positive symptoms. Let's talk negative symptoms. these are things that normal people have and can do that are taken away from some schizophrenics. negative symptoms often get worse with age and are thought to be caused by depletion of dopamine where positive symptoms are thought to be the result an excess of dopamine. Some types of Schizophrenia (prior the current DSM-5 when they differentiated between types of schizophrenia; they no longer do this) have very little positive symptoms and are almost entirely characterized by negative symptoms that are often quite severe. extreme lack of motivation to do literally anything including self care such as washing, cleaning, food preparation, etc. lack of interest in others and socializing, flattened or blunted affect (this is the ability to feel and/or express emotion), difficulty with speaking, and loss of sense of purpose which often leads to higher suicide risk. Negative symptoms as a whole often leads to drug use as a means of getting the dopamine that is missing and while it often improves negative symptoms it simultaneously increases positive symptoms. The water gets even muddier if you bring schizoaffective disorder into the equation which is basically schizophrenia combined with a mood disorder like Major Depression or Bipolar Disorder.   The experience is very unique to the individual but also to the type. one person may have extreme paranoia and hallucinations of people coming to get them, another may talk to spirits, one may have very mild hallucinations or even no hallucinations but instead basically has early onset dementia and depression like symptoms while another has catatonic episodes and just doesn't move for long periods of time. One may have elements of multiple types. one may not be able to smile while another may have inappropriate affect and burst into laughter upon hearing that a close relative has passed. The cover of the book may vary wildly but all of these people have schizophrenia.

I've had schizophrenia my whole life, which became schizoaffective depressive type because of improper treatment growing up with it as a child. I was on a pagan forum around age 18, which I worked hard to get the others to understand my thought process as someone with schizophrenia. When I became successful at it, they embraced me and how I poked fun at it. I have two voices/people I see and hear every day who like to pick on each other with humorous insults. I remember one day I asked on the forum if I could post their interactions simply because they were funny. It wasn't that they were enforcing my belief they are real, it was more so a way to help me cope, and those two men are always so kind to me. So, on the forum, they allowed me to have a thread of their interactions. And it was great. It was so much fun to poke fun at the silly things that surprisingly happened "in my head", and let others in on it, too, who weren't going to ridicule me for it. About 2 or 3 years later a woman gets on the forum and berates me for making fun of such a serious illness and that I couldn't possibly be schizophrenic if I could laugh at it.   Seeing you laugh with those two about some of the things they deal with as people with schizophrenia is so refreshing and makes me want that forum to return so I could post this and say to that woman, "See?! They have schizophrenia, too, and are able to laugh about it!"
And this is how I met Tyler Durden

When I was in the psych ward there were two ladies with schizophrenia and they were two of the sweetest people I have ever met. The ways their schizophrenia affected them was so different, even though both of them had hallucinations. The one saw demons all the time that said horrible things to her constantly, and she could only handle actually talking to people for a short time and then had to go pace the floor. The other one at one point vaulted over the staff counter because she thought she was in a Taco Bell and couldn't find her way out. She could carry on a conversation if you kept asking her questions. I sat and talked with her a lot because nobody else did.

Facing demons means trying to live a clean life, without vices, without fear, not doing things that  demages our soul, going out, partying, changing partners, drinking, smoking, masturbating, being mean, selfish, unconcious, unconcious of yourself and others, our environment, own needs, other people's needs, etc. because that's how demons are channeled. some people have it in their genetics, while others become schizophrenic due to other influences. sufferers of schizophrenia, try to face your fears, because this is the only way to beat schizophrenia. same as on lsd trip or mushrooms, as long as you resist you have a bed trip, when you face it, you get lessons and learn, mostly about yourself. don't be afraid when someone tells you "what if it's real". everything is real to you anyway when you hallucinate, and resisting only makes the situation worse. I'm just curious if there are people with schizophrenia who have tried to face their fears and what happens then. try it, you have nothing to lose, I think you can only profit. try to show these entities that they have no control over you. and by admitting to yourself that you see a different reality and gaining a deeper understanding of schizophrenia, you can begin real healing. in the past, mental illnesses were treated with psychedelics. precisely for the reasons I stated. for a better understanding of yourself and the world around you.

I was diagnosed 5 years ago, I'm 32 now. I have hallucinated for as long as I can remember. I remember when I was a child like, 7 years old it was nice things like cartoons coming out of the TV because I was lonely and had no friends and the adults kept calling them my "imaginary friends" but they were real to me. When I got older during my teenage years things got darker, like Amityville Horror so my family had me exorcized and nothing changed afterwards. Everything has been very hard for me for my whole life, but with therapy and everything I'm on the right track and I'm hoping to have my own place very soon and I'm going to see if I could figure something out to get a service dog so I have some extra help with me all the time because a lot of people don't the obstacles for schizophrenics when they don't have it themselves and to have a service dog to kind of take some of the mental load off of my memory and to be able to pet and cuddle to still get the oxytocin and feel needed will be beautiful. I'm hopeful for my future.

My father had schizophrenia that he refused to get treatment for since he believed it was all real. It put a strain on the family because of how it affected him. A lot of his delusions and auditory hallucinations were based in guilt from his past, and he talked to himself and got really worked up while doing so. Because he didn't receive treatment, he would self medicate with alcohol. This June 17, he went to work as a construction worker and had another episode after a night of drinking. He suffered a heart attack and died. This is one reason I think mental health awareness is very important because it can save lives. This disorder untreated not only was partially the cause for my father's death, but it also took away so many years of his life where instead of living, he was suffering in the hands of his disorder.

I believe consciousness isn't located in the brain, but the brain is merely a receiver for consciousness.  Consciousness is a frequency that is broadcasted through the entire universe, and brains are tuned to receive it. These people, I believe, have an error in receiving consciousness information properly through their brains, and they might have information gaps in their consciousness, which the brain then tries to fill out. Like an AI trying to draw an image. The brain will try to make up for what is missing, which in turn result in the hallucinations and delusions. That's a possibility Another possibility is that their brain might not be perfectly tuned to the right frequencies of the crisp reality. Like radio static. Both of these possible causes have to do with brainwaves.  If brainwaves are out of order, we can work on brain health to alleviate and hopefully the symptoms. Do they get enough fattyacids? Omega-3, 6 and 9? DHA and EPA? That would be a start, cause those compounds are building blocks for new neurons. Combined with Lions mane mushroom, which promotes neurogenesis, there's a part of the treatment plan. I believe intermittent fasting, the right diet treatment and a bunch of other methods might be able to cure people from this horrible experience. THANK YOU, from a mental health care, providers perspective, for addressing that DID and schizophrenia are not the same thing!!!
Schizophrenia and related disorders exist on a spectrum.  Not everyone will retain the same level of insight, cognitive ability, social skills, or emotional regulation. I wish that everyone afflicted with such a condition saw the same level of outcomes and retention of faculty as those individuals interviewed‚Ä¶  But it also could be a danger to hold everybody with schizophrenia, or schizoaffective disorder up to the standards of these individuals, in terms of control over their own behavior and insight - some people need more consistent, even invasive, help. There is no soapbox ‚Äúright answer‚Äù here for every person with these conditions.  I wish there were, but all I can say is that each person‚Äôs lived experience is valid.  Pain and distress are real, no matter the underlying understanding (or lack thereof) of their causes.

With my personal experience, I haven't been diagnosed but I think I do have it. I see shadow figures and I hear my name being called all the time out in public and at work. But I don't have extreme hallucinations like these two talked about. And most of the time the things I see happen at home. It's a shadow peeking around at me from behind my TV at night, sometimes I see it in my peripheral in public but that's it. I don't have major delusions either. Sometimes I feel bugs crawl on me and nothing's there. And I think recently I've seen bugs in my room that aren't really there. But it's not disturbing my life in big ways, so if I do have it I don't really need to rush to get this figured out if this is what it really is. At the same time I can't really tell anyone I have it because it's not official, so I don't have anyone to talk to about it. I mention it to close friends that I think I have it and they've luckily been receptive to it and haven't treated me any different. As far as I know, I‚Äôm nowhere on the schizophrenia spectrum, but as long as I can remember, I‚Äôve been hearing and seeing ‚Äúnot real‚Äù things, but they‚Äôre nearly always benign and never human. Most often, they‚Äôre just little animals, cats and dogs and like that. It‚Äôs not normally bothersome except while driving. I‚Äôve been pulled over more than once at night for swerving or braking suddenly, but the explanation of ‚ÄúI thought I saw an animal in the road‚Äù is not uncommon in somewhat-rural Georgia. I‚Äôve often wondered if it should worry me, but I have a lot more, larger mental health issues to be concerned about so I just go on with my life. I'm pretty sure I don't have schizophrenia but I do get some sort off 'hallucinations' of bugs. I've hated bugs my whole life and most of the time when i'm stressed or in a panic sort of state I see a ton of bugs on the surface that i'm walking on, or if i'm laying in bed, they're under me, besides me, EVERYWHERE. What triggers this to be worse is seeing an actual bug in my house, for instance, yesterday I was laying in bed, watching youtube on my laptop (it was night, so it was very dark). I saw through the laptop's light a cockroach's antennas on top of the laptop which led me in a shock sort of state, I jumped out of the bed, turned on the lights on to make sure I wasn't seeing things. It was running on my bed, which caused me to panic. I did kill it but after seeing an actual cockroach, neither could I fall asleep, neither could I stop seeing and feeling the bugs that aren't there crawl on my skin. Mostly these 'small' triggers cause me to see bugs everywhere and it's hard to snap out of it, every time I burst into tears because I cannot detect if they're actually there or if i'm seeing things. After killing that cockroach I wasn't sure if it was real or not until I saw it's dead body in the morning (sometimes after killing a bug I leave it on the floor to make sure the next morning if it was real or not in hopes of understanding if the next bug is actually real). Honestly all it has done for now is just let me know if the bugs i've killed were real, I haven't cracked the 'code' that would help me understand if the 'hallucinations' are just hallucinations or reality. This has been happening to me since I was very young but mostly when I had a fever or high temperature. Other cases would be when i'd try to fix the bed during the night to my 'expectations' as I have ocd, it was never good enough, so i'd get frustrated and keep moving to fix the bed, which would cause my body's temperature to rise. That's exactly when i'd start seeing bugs on my bed and I'm talking MASSIVE colonies of bugs.

My brother has this. It's been 20 years. I learn new things every day. His delusions were extremely scary in the beginning.  He thought he had accidentally murdered people and that the police were after him. He thought a sheriff came to our door and threw a human head at him and told him he did it. So he was scared of anyone in a uniform. He couldn't ride in a car, bc he would flip out if we drove by a cop. He was so scared. This was how his delusions and hallucinations began. We were lost as a family.  He felt extreme guilt thinking he had accidentally hurt someone. We at first thought maybe he had hurt someone. We didn't know it was delusions. But the more bizarre he started acting, we realized that something was very wrong. It's a very complex disorder. I wish people understood the daily fear people with this disorder go through daily.  Many people with this disorder unfortunately end their lives bc of how traumatic their condition can be. :(

I remember watching this video when it was released. I specifically watched it because at the time I thought I might be schizophrenic and I wanted to hear from other people with schizophrenia about their symptoms to see if I might be right. I realized that I had similar symptoms but not all the same.  This video, alongside another video by another creator actually made me talk about it with my psychiatrist. And in the beginning she refused to even look into it, though she knew I've had hallucinations since I was a kid. Eventually however she came to realize that I have Schizoaffective disorder and I was diagnosed with it. Today 2 different psychiatrist have assured me that I have this "illness". The reason for this is because I still get in denial and think I might have imagined everything as I am on meds and don't experience the symptoms as much.  Also, I must say that it is a bit sad how many people get afraid when you mention this, as most people know it from horror movies and only see the very worst side of it.

My moms uncle had Schizophrenia. I never knew him, as he died in '73, and I was born in '07. He had 2 attempts on suicide, and never had to do a third. He tried both times (and succeeded the second) to get hit by trains.
My mother was schizophrenic. She passed away in 2009 and I‚Äôve avoided learning much about it because my own experiences with my mom really scared me as a kid, and made me feel so helpless to help her. You all did a fantastic job at clearing some of my confusion up. Especially you, Cecilia. Thanks you guys so much
If you ever feel like doing a sequel please hit me up.  I have Schizoaffective Disorder and frequently go into Manic Psychotic Episodes. Ohh and I also refuse to take any anti psychotics or mood enhancers, Ive accepted who I am and how my mind works Choosing to live in a world full of magical and fantastic things then to live my life within the socially accepted confines of a tiny box people are comfortable with.
This reminds me of this one guy in my old school started calling me schizo out of nowhere, and when i asked him about it he said it was because it looked like i was talking to someone that wasnt there, then i told him i was just singing along to a song i was listening to. So to some people that see this, please dont just call people schizo out of nowhere.
I always find it so interesting to listen to other schizophrenics experiences.   I was diagnosed as schizophrenic at the end of 2021, after a four month long psychotic episode that I have absolutely no recollection of. But I've been told a lot about it and it was pretty.   Ive been dealing with it since i was a little girl. My first experience was in first grade, in the cafeteria at school. I kept hearing my name, like a whisper, but above all the noise and talking of the other kids, like it was right there in my ear. And I remember i kept asking people if they were hearing my name and everyone was confused. And i looked around the cafeteria and in the center of the room, jesus was just standing there with this warm glowing light, calling my name. That didnt affect me much, I thought it was strabge but i moved on. Then i was convinced i was the child of Poseidon for years, powers and all. And my best friend thought it was real, we spent a lot of time at the beach and he'd say "Jynx, ask him for bigger waves"- that sounds so silly but i truly believed had the ability to directly speak to Poseidon. By high school i was having terrible tactile and visual hallucinations surrounding bugs. I would cut my skin open to try and dig them out, or burn myself to try and kill them. I saw bugs everywhere, i would scrub my skin absolutely raw trying to cleanse myself, i took four showers a day. It was bad enough that my gynecologist refused any implants (the ones in the arm or IUDs) because of my history- she was worried i would have an episode and rip it out of my body.   As an adult, its gotten even worse. I see glitches in reality and can see underneath what they show us. Sometimes I'm taken to another world where everything looks the same, but its very different, and someone is experiment on me. Sometimes the people around me are replaced. Sometimes I believe I'm dead and I'm just a corpse. Sometimes my arms arent mine, they belong to someone else and someone sewed them on my body, and they did it backwards and its so physically discomforting and so scary that i start to feel massive urges to cut my limbs off.   The worst part, for me, is that i can never, ever trust my own version of reality. Even medicated. I have to question everything. Is this person real? Is that a real bug? Is my skin itching because of something physical or mental? Did that stop light actually turn green/red or am I about to cause an accident and die? Every piece of my universe has to be fact checked by someone else in order for me to feel safe.

I room with someone with schizophrenia, and their delusions manifested strongest when tired, stressed, alone, and just not alert to keep check of their delusions themselves. Meaning a lot of times the episodes I'm aware of come on in the middle of the night and they're screaming in their room because they wake up thinking someone is attacking and choking them or our house is on fire and they're trapped in.  If I'm around and awake during an episode, I try to use my best calm voice to call their name, ask them to hold my hand and let's walk to the kitchen to get some water or go outside for some resh air, slowly talk them through how to unlock their bedroom door to begin with, crack some light jokes to distract her, things like that. I've asked them before if there's anything I can do to help, but they weren't very comfortable talking about it so I didn't ask again beyond letting them know I'll take any feedback whenever wherever.  But I'm glad to hear from this video that acting normal, calm, and not overreacting IS a good way to help. I didn't mess up or make it worse in any case haha. But they're really a sweetheart and I could never imagine them harming a single soul.
if anyone here experiences schizophrenic symptoms, i'd like to hear if you have thoughts on the matter of how to be supportive of people who are experiencing disorganized thinking and/or hallucinations while retaining healthy boundaries. i've been volunteering with the houseless community for a few years now so i've encountered a lot of neurodivergent and schizophrenic people, and have had a couple partners who have schizophrenic symptoms. as a neurotypical person who wants to show my solidarity and support, i want to be as empathetic as possible, but honestly it gets to be pretty uncomfortable and emotionally draining when i'm locked in conversation with someone who is speaking incoherently to me for an extended period of a time.  i've had to just walk away from people directly engaging me sharing nonsensical, erratic or delusional thoughts, in a way that felt rude and insensitive, just for my own mental health. i want to be respectful and helpful, but i need to have boundaries to manage my energy and anxiety. it just seems like a very gray area that is hard to set. does anyone have experiences or thoughts with this?

A while ago I thought my brother had schizophrenia. He was having delusions, visual and auditory hallucinations, and serious paranoia. He thought he was on the Truman show, and the whole world was watching him, he thought the cops were going to arrest him, or even kill him, despite him not engaging in any criminal activity, and he thought that everyone knew him, and celebrities were talking about him, watching him, writing songs about him, etc. Any weird coincidence that had any relevance to what was going on with him became more proof that everything he said was real. He accused me and our parents of being in on it, that we sold him out for money and let people secretly film him. It was pretty messed up. Nothing could convince him otherwise, I tried talking rationally to him for hours, many times over the course of months. I even took apart all our TVs just to try to prove to him that they didn‚Äôt have cameras hidden inside them. Anyway, it turned out he was taking some supplements he bought online. Don‚Äôt trust those astronaut drugs, brain enhancers, or dietary supplements pills, they are junk Russian drugs that aren‚Äôt rigorously tested, that only God and Putin know what the hell is actually in them. He specifically took phenibut. He apparently took them for years and had no adverse reactions, and then it started negatively affecting his memory, (ironic, since it claims to stimulate memory and thought) and he would forget he took them and end up taking even more of them. The doctors had no idea what it was, and he saw like 5 of them, until I found a bottle and had a hunch and looked up the side effects and they were spot on. He ended up going to a psych ward for a short time, and he got better. He‚Äôs mostly good now, other than spending a lot of time thinking about how crazy the whole experience was, it‚Äôs definitely affected him. I‚Äôm just glad I got my brother back. I just wanted to warn everybody to stay away from that garbage. It makes me wonder how many people might be in the psych ward, right now, diagnosed with disorders like schizophrenia just because they took some crap and didn‚Äôt know what was in it, and the effects mimic schizophrenia pretty much perfectly, and doctors don‚Äôt seem to know anything about this. I still don‚Äôt think the doctors would‚Äôve figured it out on their own to this day. It‚Äôs not a well known issue. Careful what you ingest, and be safe out there yall.

Please approve for publication; So sad, anyone who has looked after a loved one with mental illness or dementia will know how hard it is physically and mentally. One of the hardest things in the world is mourning someone who is still alive. My son was diagnosed with schizophrenia 5years ago, with a series of life-threatening symptoms of hallucinations, delusion, and depression, Even with rigorous therapies, antipsychotic medications, and some controversial alternative treatments the condition didn't improve. Today, it makes¬†2years since my son recovered after taking Consummo treatment without any treatment, he is now living a complete, normal, healthy life and has returned to college. I wanted to take the time to encourage you never to give up, It is not my intent to persuade or convince anyone, nor should it be considered a replacement for sound medical advice but rather for you to know there is an optional treatment, completely natural and has no side effects.¬† While everyone's journey is unique, numerous patients with paranoid schizophrenia are effectively treated and cured with their mode of treatment.

I used to work with a man who had schizophrenia. He was the sweetest man ever. It developed because of excessive acid usage in the 60s. Even now all this time later he still sees shadows and hears whispers and feels like he's being stalked. He said it happens a lot less with therapy but for a while his insurance got screwed up and he had to stop going and he was in fear 24/7 afraid someone was in his house or following him at work. It got to the point where he would hear a high pitch woman scream and he freaked tf out and run out of wherever he was.

I'm still in disbelief at how complex this illness is. I used to be a support worker for vulnerable adults, I had absolutely no experience and I was thrown straight in supporting many adults with schizophrenia, and I was not prepared or trained at all. I got major backlash from my bosses when I said I am in no way qualified or trained enough to give them the level of help and support they need. It was so unfair on the clients themselves, and honestly just made our company look like incompetent idiots. üòû

O_O I guess I wasn't sure how much I actually believed it, but I had a notion that I was spiritually sensitive and could see ghosts and stuff. I struggle with auditory hallucinations, I'll hear voices but they aren't speaking a specific language, it's like quickly changing radio stations and getting snippets of sound or voices, then I'll get deep voices as a commentary - like "Oh, is he going to wash his hands after using the bathroom?" And my thoughts will be like, "why wouldn't I?" but not in my head, like, as though someone is next to me, my internal thought has a voice, but then I'll hear these outside external voices, at the same time as the thought.  It actually feels loud, even though I know there's no sound. A microphone would actually hear just ambient room noise or typical room noises like a heater or water pipes, etc and my head is filled with voices or strange rings or pops, then incoherent female or deep male voices. The delusional voices will always tell me I'll never amount to anything, that my existence and being alive is a mistake, and when I do something I'm actually proud of- I'll feel like it wasn't right to let people know my accomplishments or that I did something. Even writing this comment, I just heard, "random strangers don't need to know your business because you're just a crazy person, too"  My actual diagnosis is Depressive Psychosis
I'm glad that there's videos like this to educate people about this disorder. Cause every time I tell someone that I have paranoid schizophrenia. I feel like they have no idea what it is and what it's like. Videos like this kinda help me explain what's going on with me. I'm really not that great with my choice of words and I can come off a kinda dumb when I'm trying to explain my feelings or whatever. Hopefully people can become more understanding about this disorder and stop alienating people that suffer from this, because we didn't ask to be this way..

Okay. Recently I was on the form of medication. I'm not going to say why I was on it or what the medication was obviously. But it caused me to have hallucinations. Very mild nothing like faceless people or demons. But even if that was simply a sliver of what it's like to have schizophrenia I would be so scared. Because I was in school one day. It was a field trip day I wasn't going on the field trip. So I have the class was gone there was like me and three other students. I walked into the classroom and there were 17 other kids who I did not know. But I still knew that there were only three other students. I could see those three other students and I knew that I was there under the teacher was there I had to ignore all the other ones. And the reason I knew that they weren't there is cuz they weren't wearing the school uniform. Cuz I go to a private school that we can't like just wear normal clothes you have to wear uniform we also can't have her phone so it can do the phone trick. Also I never knew the phone trip was a thing. But that terrified me. Because they did seem real although  there was one kid who is missing a hand. And another that was missing a big patch of hair on the back of his head.

I have a team member with schizophrenia but never told us. Before I knew that she had any struggles with mental health, I once spoke to her about her work performance being not up to par. She cried and I tired to be encouraging, telling her that I believed in her and that she could do it. Little did I know that this talk, coupled with other things going on in her life, caused her stress and triggered her. She would stand there and laugh at nothing, talk to herself, appear like she was in a daze etc. She was also hospitalised at a mental institution for a few days. I only learnt afterwards (from another team member she worked with) that she had schizophrenia. I think schizophrenia can be one of those extremely difficult mental disorders that might cause them into physical harm. If you know someone who have schizophrenia, please do not try to trigger them. Respect their behavior and always lead them to the reality (without them realizing what you're trying to do).  Maybe you can use physical touch like handshake  or hugging them.   I think the best way to interact with them is to not provoke them about their condition especially specifying or emphasizing their kind of delusions. Please be kind to them.   On the brighter side, I think there might be people who have schizophrenia that are not that bad. They might be hallucinating of nice stuffs like seeing unicorns, fairies or anything nice. But this really depends on each person who have this diagnosis.
I'm a med student and physicians and psychiatrists (in Brazil at least) say that these hallucinations are actually shadows, glimpses of light/darkness and aren't as detailed as described. And if they talk about seeing aliens, ufos, clowns, and more specific "things" it's more of a mystical side, and not schizo... And schizophrenia is very incapacitating, those who are able to get out of the psychosis state and control with meds etc are never gonna be 100% functional again, and often work in less demanding jobs. It really makes me wonder how these people are so lucid and understand so well their disease, it's different from everything I've seen in my psychiatry rotations. Very interesting video, it's very mind opening.

I was staying in a psych ward for bipolar depression and alcoholism from trying to self medicate and the girl I shared a room with had schizophrenia and hallucinations of a little girl persistently trying her to harm herself. It really moved me and still does to think of her experiences and how strong she was to be getting through it. She actually taught me how she deals with persistent thoughts thoughts and it was a different perspective that I heard in addiction circles and I used her technique and thought of her courage long after meeting her. Having bipolar 2 depressive type I've had the opportunity to meet a lot of people in treatment with schizophrenia and a childhood friend had it. There is such a stigma because as a society we only tend to notice if someone has a mental illness by witnessing them during an episode, but when you meet people with schizophrenia they are just normal people dealing with an illness and trying to go about their lives.

During my stay at an adolescent mental hospital, the first thing they told us was not to talk about peoples conditions or acknowledge certain things like outbursts or delusions/hallucinations  I remember there was a boy who was going through drug withdrawals who had schizophrenia and he was probably the most quiet person I ever met. The idea that people assume schizophrenia makes people dangerous to others honestly boils my blood.  His hallucinations almost always caused him extreme fear, there was one case where around 4 AM he sprinted down the hallway where my room happened to be and slammed full force into locked doors to escape something that was chasing him. Another time he had to scrub his hands clean at the nurses station because he could see black ink on his hands and body and it was causing him severe distress. He ended up being moved to a facility better equipped to help him because he was screaming in terror and throwing he and his roommates belongings at a corner of his room  In between and during these moments none of the other teens I was with experienced fear or discomfort with him being around us. I think a key aspect in him helping be comfortable was that we didnt talk about his previous episodes or treat him any different  The idea that grown adults show less empathy and understanding then a group of mentally ill and paranoid teenagers is appalling
I'm diagnosed with schizoaffective disorder, which is a combination of schizophrenia and bipolar disorder. I was diagnosed when I was fifteen, and I'm twenty-one now. I have both auditory and visual hallucinations.  The scariest one I've ever had was I was in a hospital room, and the bed was up against the wall. All of a sudden, I thought a group of people was surrounding me, pointing at me, just yelling and accusing me of things. Thankfully, the nurses let me move to a bed in the hall, making me feel safer.  Whenever I tell people I have schizophrenia, they're always more curious than scared. I get asked, "What's that like?" More often than anything. I do love educating people and sharing my experiences.
A Hallucination is something that is not there that you see is a illusion, something that is there that you cannot see
Hey Anthony! Can you please interview people with depersonalization and derealization disorder?
I have Schizo-Affective Disorder (and ASD), which is basically Schizophrenia with a mood disorder. It‚Äôs really freeing knowing that what I experience isn‚Äôt an isolated event. So many people don‚Äôt understand the difference between external and internal auditory hallucinations, and external hallucinations can be confusing and disorienting, so it was so nice to be reassured that what I hear and see happens to others like me. It can be really difficult to navigate in life with this disorder, some days just trying to function ‚Äúnormally‚Äù takes 110% of my energy and just an average day at work can become confusing and terrifying by the end of the day. If you are on the Schizophrenic spectrum, or have any mental illness, I just want you to know that you‚Äôre not broken, you‚Äôre not ‚Äúcrazy‚Äù- you just experience life differently. You are a human, and you deserve love and compassion. You are not a monster‚Äî you are a person, and don‚Äôt let anyone make you feel otherwise ‚ù§

I have a family friend who's recently been diagnosed with schizophrenia and it's been incredibly difficult on his family. He used to be one of the sweetest people I knew, wouldn't hurt a fly. But as his schizophrenia started developing, he was acting more and more bizarre. Claimed to be going to class when he dropped out of school, went on long walls to God knows where for hours at a time and became incredibly socially isolated. Until one day he attacked his sister over a video game, both siblings have black belts so someone could've seriously gotten injured. The final straw for his family was when he tried to kill his own mother by strangling and repeatedly hitting her head against the bathroom wall. Scary part was that they were the only 2 in the house (sis and dad were outside of the house, not too far) and he shoved his fingers down her throat to prevent her from screaming. Eventually the cops had to be called and he was taken away to a hospital where he got officially diagnosed. I wasn't very close with him but it makes my heart bleed knowing how their family will never be the same again. Not all cases of schizophrenia turn out like this one, but he possibility of it isn't none.

A few days ago my brother said he saw a fingers coming from the door but wasn't exactly touching the door, and a week or two ago I would see people and if I let myself then I will sometimes see buildings as their like ran down version, and some other things but it mostly happens at school or while my dad or mom or sometimes aunt is driving, it once happened at my boyfriend's house but I never told him, I seen like his restroom as if it was like 400 years later and no one touched the house so things were all weird and stuff. Sometimes it could be worst but thats very rare in my case. Oh and sometimes I would see my grandma or what I last remember her looking like, out side of my school building through a window just watching me. I told very few people because I was scared of how my friends would react, about a year of me first realizing I was actually seeing people I told my boyfriend and he was worried about something happening to me.

i have an auntie who has both untreated autism and schizophrenia. as a kid, i could clearly tell something about her was different, but she never harmed anyone so i was never scared of her. i hung out with her, talked to her, lent her my dolls so she could design and sew dresses for them. she is fascinated with fashion and very talented too, the dresses she made for our dolls was all handsewn with love and care, and they were haute couture level of craftmanship. that woman is a hecking goat when it comes to fashion.  a random summer day when i was 17, my dad (her brother) pulled me aside and told me that basically, my auntie got "possessed" by an evil spirit or a demon, i can't recall. she had been having problems with hallucination leading to that point, but for some reason, she had a mental breakdown which triggered a full blown psychosis episode that lasted a whole month. one hour she was fine, the next she was screaming for help because she thought my grandma kidnapped her when she was a child, that the bearded man who communicated with her in tongues was her real father trying to claim her back. the next hour, she was back to normal again. this cycle got so out of hand that my grandma had to get her exorcised to turn her back to "normal". this shit only stopped when my auntie fainted mid ritual because she couldn't handle it anymore, the shaman who conducted the exorcism then had the fucking audacity to tell my grandma my auntie had been cleansed off "the evil" and she would be "normal" soon. which is the most bullshity thing i've ever heard in my life.  i told my dad she showed symtomps of schizophrenia and that continual exorcisms would only worsen her condition, we should get her professional help instead. but as you can see, he was not happy with my conclusion, saying that there is no way his sister is "broken like that naturally". the result is that my auntie got so traumatised she can't make a single coherent sentence again, only speaking in gibberish. she has turned into a shadow of her former self. i almost feel pity for her, but there were moments when she looked at how i dress, her face would light up and she would compliment my outfit choice. it was like she was truly living and breathing again. moments like that reminds me that she is still very much a person with hopes and dreams, her true self is just hidden behind a mental disorder. i am glad that i was able to bring her out, even just for a split second.

Her sister knew, because he was very open, and honest with her about it all, but we (my friend and I) only knew he had it, we knew nothing about it. When Kody started to talk about the scissors it reminded me of a time when I was at my friends house and her sister had her friend over and he walked out into the livingroom with scissors in his hand. He had a blank look on his face and then went after my friend. I remember it as a scary/crazy situation because I had no idea why he was doing what he was doing. He didn't hurt her, he stood there for a moment, that look went away and he saw what he was doing and how scared my friend was and he backed off, said sorry, and walked away. My friend told her sister she didn't want him to come around anymore so they had to hang out at other places. To us it was weird/scary behavior, but now hearing Kody's story of not remembering getting the scissors it makes me feel bad about how everyone reacted. We were ignorant we had no idea about it, and I feel if it was talked about in school maybe that evening would have went different.

The delusions tha kody stated he had are actually very similar to mine. Some days at school i would have a complete zoned out experience where i saw myself in a void, and then i started to belive tha all the mere coincidences that happened in my life was a part of a simulation or something in the lines of that. I thought tha i was a person moving through a void while my life was just a dream unfolding in front of my eyes. Pretty scary and certainly not helpful when i was trying to concentrate, yet it didnt happen very often. As a small kid, and sometimes now, i used to have these repetitive dreams where i could see the organs in my body while there would just be static sound to it. Wat was so strange about these dreams is i felt awake, i could feel my body moving yet my eyes would not open. The image of my own organs moving around and somehow pulsating would still be there. There was no reason tha i would have dreamt this since it started when i was round 5 or 6, i never really saw organs at all, closest thing to it was be a bloody nose or a scratch tha bled out at bit, and they werent in no way as gory as my dreams turned out to me. Tried searching for anything tha might cause both of those things, found nothing :(

I have anxity and i was convinced that i have schizophrenia
Weirdly in South Africa many people that are diagnosed with schizophrenia usually seek traditional healers(Sangoma) to help them out. Sangomas say that everything has some connections with spirits. So they give you medicines that are dug up in forests and Savannahs. The medicines used are 1000's of years old and the plants needed to obtain the medicines are passed down from generation to generation. So basically you are given a medicine that you set on fire in your house, one that you bath in, and one that you drink. And while you do that you should be praying to your ancestors to guide you through life. And trust me it works like crazy.  I was having extreme hallucinations and delusions. I would go days without almost 0 sleep. It was terrible. I was diagnosed with schizophrenia but my mom said we should do what our ancestors did when they had mental issues. It worked after 3 days of doing those three things for three days in a row. I was amazed. I went to sleep in my own bad after a year(15yo at the time). I left my special needs school and went to normal school. My life changed and respect to that woman. Most Southern Africans know about Sangomas (or Inhanga).

I thought the title said "I spent a day w/ ARGENTINIANS" for a bit
I am diagnoced with paranoid schizophrenia.  My first symptom's came when I was 4 years old. I was in kindergarten and told a caregiver that "the man says i should just die". Nobody took that serious and it was first when I was 15 years old i was attacked by a swarm of bugs (not real) and went in to complete panic that people started to question if something was wrong. I went to my doctor and was sent to a therapist. They diagnosed me with schizotypical disorder ( I'm from Denmark and at the time it was not allowed to diagnose schizophrenia on a child) i started to tell them was i was seeing and hearing (i thought everyone experienced this) i was hearing 2 male voices besided my head, one was mean and wanted to hurt me, the other was kind to me, like a devil and Angel situation. I saw blood dripping from the sealing, water looked like and tasted like blood. I saw big snakes on the ground and enormous spiders (1 meter tall and with 3 eyes) i even saw my loved ones face change to a demon face if i was with them for more than 2 hours.i was not scared of any of these things.  I got some medications that unfortunately made me aggressive so i stopped taking it.  When I was 18 i had a panic attack where i believed i was having a heart attack. They took me to the hospital and i was not having any physical problems so they told me to walk over to a unit for patient's who needed psychiatric help quickly. They would not admit me and just gave me an appointment with a psychiatrist one month later.  I went to this appointment and in 30 minutes he diagnosed me with paranoid schizophrenia. I was in chok, i thought people with that disorder was dangerous bad people who killed people and changed personalitys, i even once heard someone say that you should never turn your back to a person with schizophrenia becourse they will attack you.  I was in chok and was admitted to the psyck ward for 3 days.   I now know that it's a really small percentage who gets dangerous, and its almost always people who sought help and was denied help. People with schizophrenia does not change personality and those with DID who does have more than one personality is not dangerous.   My best friend through 15 years would now not be my friend becourse i was scary, i told her i had those symptoms for all the time she new me and i was still the same person but she would not listen.  I have been rejected in the dating becourse i have this.  I have been told that if i ever get pregnant they will most likely take my baby away right after birth.  My drivers license is only for 2 years at a time, i have to get it renewed every 2 years.   Now these are the negative effects of getting the diagnose.   The good things are that now i no longer see things there is not there, i dont hear voices, water is just water. I can relax with my family and friends. I feel great and are Happy. I am now out of the system and live a healthy happy life and i am really grateful i got the help i needed.   So if you are experiencing any symtoms please seek help, it will be Worth it in the end, don't postpone your road to a happy healthy life.

as someone without schizophernia, here is my best interpretation of hallucinations. your brain picks up external data, interprets that data, relays that to the senses, and that's your reality, but now its picking up data that isnt there and its taking that non existent data and relaying to the sensing to perceive it anyway. so the brain unconsciously imagines things that could exist, then misclassifies that thought as something that does exist, puts it under external data received, and your senses pick then pull that as real.

Its interesting.  Think about what sleep is. Why do some people see whole worlds in their minds at night during sleep.  That form is normal. But if your dreams enter into your wakeing life. Thats not normal. Thats more of a safety thing. For example walking straight into a car you couldnt see because you were on a grassy open feild.  What i am trying to state is. That sounds like a thing our brains have been told to develop unconciousely. And people are experiencing the ability  to turn it on. But not learn how to turn it off.  This is a form of imprisonment where we are told to ask another rather then deal with it in our selves.  I see many things in night dreams. Places i have never seen in life or on line/books. Movies show the same format , grand places, big ideas.. .. . Inventions and machines.  Everything humans built , was a form of day dream. My mind can build visually inside its self. But i do not have the tools to see it as clear as i have seen night dreams. If this ability were expressed to a physical point outside my body. My thought would be, i would want to know which 'button' to press to internalize it. Not have a medical 'button' surpress the ability by harbouring me more drowsy.  Surrpression is the format of medication i believe they give out and give many names to.  When i stated below about the faces. Because in this video he talks of seeing faces change. This came about through a form of tiredness. I developed it through time. It began by defocusing my eyes and learning to keep staring through light placement. After staring at the moon when it was full for a while (months) i began being able to dis place the light and hold the refocus on the object. By doing that the light changed as most filtered away from the moon. The res of the light tightened and became lines, circuling the moon. The symbol it - the moon, will resembel is the science logo or it is none as the lotus flower. These are prerecored symbols established already which i drew from memorie when i saw it in the moon. I figured that was how those people came to term it- symbolically.  So anyone can do it. With patients. The moon will begin to look:  white on the outside. Orange or yellow on the inside. Like an egg. Then if you can keep holding eye contact. You will begin seeing sharpe white lines incirceling the moon.   Some say its a delusion. Some dont beleive unless easily in frount. My point is when did we stop beleiveing in what we can become when we redevelope a problem. Looking at is as something that can become structured and utilized for something greater.  It is a superpower to see something to experience something and to begin to safely understand it.  Through the excercise of defucusing my eyes. I was working with my eyes.  And they became better. I was able to lesson my prescription.  I have never beleived in the thought of add onto glasses prescription making them strongering and thinking eyes cant heal them selves.  That is why i led my self into trying to see clearer without an ever stronger perscription.

i am diagnosed and some days i am completely convinced i am the only person alive and every one else can read my mind. it is scary feeling like i‚Äôm the only person in the world and so i feel i cannot trust anyone. I do take meds and they help a lot. episodes usually happen while im kinda out of it, for example when im under the influence of drugs (which i don‚Äôt do anymore), or when im falling asleep or waking up
I have a question for hopefully a part 2: You guys mentioned you had delusions, and that people often underestimated what you could do in life, your dreams and so on. How do you differentiate between your dreams, your goals and your delusions?  One of the delusions mentioned was thinking he was in a coma.  My brother's delusions are thinking magic is real.. He talks about reading people's aura's, reading people's minds, hearing their thoughts.   In the past he has mentioned that he heard our grandfathers' voices - both of them - even though they were long gone. It was voices of people he knew, I'm not sure if he has had different voices of unknown origin. But I wonder... Could reading minds or hearing people's thoughts not be the delusion but be the voices he hears. He could fit instance hear that I said someone to him and that's why he could get angry thinking it was something I said.  I just noticed it was all a character or unknown voices or faces. But never anyone they knew. I would love to hear from those with schizophrenia where they do hear specifically the voices or see people they know, dead or alive.   The other thing though is that my brother has this idea that he would love to own a property (like or grandfather did) and have horses. Or he talks about building his own boat. He used to do metal work, so is pretty good at building or designing things. It's a shame I couldn't get him into painting or those community life drawing classes... Coz that would have helped a lot. Though he has taken to playing the guitar again which is awesome.  But unlike dreams it is a "I'm going to build this boat" or when I build this it's gonna be great. It's like the delusions and dreams have blended into one for him. So how do people with this illness pull those apart and work on something tangible? When she said that she is underestimated, that she had goals and dreams, it immediately made be feel guilty as I pass these goals or dreams off as the delusion as well. But in the past 5-10 years my family and I have kind of been more positive towards it. Because he seemed happy to talk about those things all day. But then maybe it is all over big delusion for him as it's more of a coping mechanism? Talk about what you enjoy, even if it might be happen, but it makes you look towards something, rather than nothing at all.   My brother doesn't have a full time job anymore, every time he tried to get back to work, he couldn't handle the stress and would spiral downhill again. So is on pension. But I wonder if having some sort of building maybe wood carving hobby would help.   But it would be great to see how people with schizophrenia are able to have working lives or part time working lives. Or hobbies and how that helps them cope. Or really any sort of disorder or condition, doesn't have to just be schizophrenia. I think that would be great to hear about and will help those with these conditions that aren't able to fully function, so they can find things they can enjoy or do to make themselves feel more worthwhile, validated and feel great about themselves.
Thank you so much for sharing this! And not to diminish what these guys said, as it's been super informative and an eye opener, but people can get violent. However it's normally because they are scared or confused, or its self defence for them as they are scared of being hurt. My brother was diagnosed with schizophrenia when he was around 22. He also had depression though so maybe it was a part of that.  My experience was that he didn't know what was real or not. I also didn't know how to deal with him being the way he was as I was only in highschool. And this was back in early 2000 so there wasn't an much information on schizophrenia back then. But in times when it got really bad and I didn't handle it well. I would get frustrated, angry and also scared, especially when he would suddenly get angry at me over the slightest thing I did or thing I said, which now I guess he was also hearing other voices so maybe they would say something mean to him or said I did something. I am not sure.  But my brother would get angry and scared and lash out at me, in one particular case he stomped really hard onto my foot (he was a lot older than me so yeah it frikin hurt like hell for days).  But I was also upset because my brother was a super nice and thoughtful person and thankfully still is. So at the time a lot of my anger and upset part was because it felt like I had lost my brother and I didn't know how to interact with this one.   But a long time has past since then. Thankfully he finally was able to see that he had this condition and he needed to take the medication so he could enjoy life again and have some sort of functioning, and hopefully less fear and chaos. He's still sorry thoughtful, loves finding out how my week has been, has some really great friends who accept him as he is, and yeah, it's life changing going on medication.   So I just wanted to spend the time right now to thank you Anthony for this video and everyone on here for sharing their experiences because it does help us understand and appreciate what these people go through and hopefully show a better response to people we know or if we come across people with this illness in the future and hopefully be a be support beacon for them. üòä

These disorders are still very recently discovered and we will definitely learn more about them in the next few decades.   My husband was originally diagnosed with a disassociative disorder by a psychologist, then a couple years later diagnosed with schizophrenia from a psychiatrist. I believe disassociative disorders and schizophrenic disorders are linked as a spectrum itself. One side being protective schizophrenia, the other destructive schizophrenia.   Wouldn‚Äôt be surprised if DID, once known and believed as a multiple personality disorder, will be named something like protective disassociative schizophrenia. Just like Aspergers and autism used to be separate disorders themselves and now on the spectrum of high functioning to lower functioning autism.   I‚Äôm fascinated where the research takes us, hopefully create better diagnosis processes and treatments, because it‚Äôs hard to even get the correct treatment for schizophrenia. That‚Äôs a journey in itself, and it‚Äôs so saddening seeing loved ones suffer through this journey.  There is not one medication that can help and sometimes even the side affects can make it worse for the person, until the best one for them is found.
I'm a teenager on the schizophrenic spectrum, I really appreciate whenever we're just presented as normal people
i did mental health first aid training in college and one of the activities we did was get into groups of three, roll up a piece of paper into a tube, and then designate roles. one person would experience an "auditory hallucination," one would be conversing with said person, and the other would be the hallucination. the "hallucination" took the tube of paper and put it up the the one experiencing the hallucination and read a script of some of the stuff people can hear during them. during this the one experiencing it had to try to maintain a conversation with the other person. i think it gave a good insight into it not just "being voices in their head" but rather show that it can be outside of the body like what was kind of described in the video.

He's treated now thank goodness, and I'm glad that there's more treatments available today.

She wasn‚Äôt ever going to hurt someone like that. It was just an expression of frustration to get it out of her body. I really wished they talked about first getting treatment/diagnosis especially as most people with schizophrenia are not aware of their disconnect from reality whatsoever. My brother has severe paranoia, delusions (typically persecutory although others have been noted), and negative symptoms, too. He also seems to suffer from hypochondriasis, regularly complaining of a myriad of different health issues resulting in emergency room visits that amount to nothing. He's 30 and has never been employed, lives at home with our mother. She doesn't know what to do, so she's offered him an ultimatum; seek treatment or get evicted. Honestly, she can't do anything else for him because he hasn't physically harmed himself or others despite his numerous outbursts (throwing things, yelling), meaning he can't be admitted against his will and he doesn't think he's suffering from psychosis so he likely won't admit himself.
My best friend has schizophrenia/psychosis with primarily positive symptoms (negative symptoms include anhedonia and catatonic states).  Fact: people with schizophrenia are more likely to suffer from violence and harm done to them.  Fact: people with schizophrenia are far LESS likely to be the cause of violence than the general population.  I've also had to explain to a lot of people that what they described as "schizophrenia" was actually Multiple Personality Disorder or DID, so I'm glad you guys touched on thatml.  My only request for this video would be - the visuals could be fairly distressing to my friend, but I would like to share it with them so they can have the experience of feeling connected to other people who understand their daily reality. Is there any chance you could make a copy of this video that DOESN'T have all the creepy clowns and shadow people and jarring cutaways? It makes it more real for folks who are trying to understand the disorder, but maybe it makes it harder for people with schizophrenia to actually watch?  Thanks so much! I'm not sure if I have schizophrenia, but I've been having auditory hallucinations since December 2021. I hear my name being whispered when I'm alone, and it's almost like a broken record. Sometimes, the end of my name is prolonged, so it sounds like the disembodied voice is whispering, "-Aaahhhh."  I was in a very abusive relationship (sexual, physical, mental, emotional) for three years, which most likely triggered my auditory hallucinations after I left my abuser.  Other times, I've heard the voice narrate what they were doing: "I'm whispering to you, slut."  One day, I heard the voice speak clearly with the word, "Crazy." That was the only time I didn't hear a whispered voice. It would be just like if someone was actually talking to me.  It gets worse when I'm alone and trying to sleep. It feels like it's just one voice that doesn't know when to be quiet, even though he whispers to me. I say "he" because it sounds like a male voice.  To be honest, I was scared. But I let my doctor and therapist know, and I was put on new medication. I'm unsure if it's actually working yet, because I still hear him.
Okay, if I am in person with someone who has schizophrenia and they say "look i have schizophrenia, and the only way 4 me to see if you're real or not is with my camera" I'd like ok no problem, but without a preface I might be a bit freaked out being recorded or touched
It sucks that most of the time I just have to go by as being crazy :/

I do not have schizophrenia, I have severe crippling depression, intense anxiety, and ptsd. I use to see a black shadow figure when I was in elementary and when I would tell others it would confuse them. One time I had told my teacher and she was worried due to her not seeing the shadow figure she generally thought it was a man. I had to stay in a office so they would be sure I was safe, now at the time my mom had known about it and it was the beginning of my therapy as well so on my papers they have it written down that I use to see that shadow figure and besides what happen at school there was a time where it got more extreme to the point I had ran into my house dropping my back pack and automatically started drawing the shadow figure and what I would here it tell me. My Aunt had saw and she needed to call my mom cause only she knew my coping skills and how to 'bring me back'. The shadow man eventually went away though I stopped seeing him but I would hear voices say my name randomly and eventually I thought I had some type of abilities. At those times besides the shadow figure which my psychiatrist and therapist checks up on me to see if the shadow comes back. I didn't think much about it until.. two weeks ago now due to ptsd I have trouble leaving my restroom at night due to the feeling of someone being there or getting into my house and this is very important because those moments only happened in the middle of the night when no one is awake, it would take me 30 minutes until I finally calm down and open the door, pet my dog  to remind me she'll warn us if anyone comes in. The two last whole weekends was me being overly paranoid due to having a feeling someone was watching me, the cars/ people going pass me or being near me and on top. It got to the point where I needed my friends to walk me home so they could distract me or else I wasn't going to be going home. Dealing with that I started to actually hear people talk in the next room that weren't my family's voices but what didn't help was I had thought and could have sworn I heard someone as well scrolling through things on the TV none stop, I was unsure it was real and I needed the dishes done but I couldn't do them and I tried calling my dog but I didn't call her name the first time so I tried texting and calling my friends but they didn't answer so I had to call my dog again cause I wasn't sure if what was happening was real and LUCKLY she came and distracted me, I was able to check the living room and no one was there the people that I thought I heard I couldn't hear no more. Another major incident that happen was I had just got off a call from someone and after a few minutes I thought I heard an animal shift around the backpacks on the bench and I knew it wasn't my dog cause she doesn't really know how to get on things if somethings there in her way it confuses her. I ended up having to call a friend and explain what was going on and she helped distract me from what was going on and brought me back. I've been thinking about telling my therapist because I've never been in those situations especially if I'm unsure if they are real or not but I guess I have voices that tell me I shouldn't because I don't want to be looked at crazy or anything but at the same time I don't think I can continue on with not telling my therapist cause eventually it's going to get to much for me.

I'm not schizophrenic, but have been in and out of various mental health treatments since I was 10/11 for various reasons, but a big one is that I am not always able to tell whether or not I'm awake/in reality. I luckily recognised something was wrong and asked for help when I was still young, but I could have been spared a lot of anxiety if we would just Teach Children About Mental Illness! When I was at the psych ward for my Schizophrenia, it was so interesting hearing about other patients delusions... one girl I befriended thought she was a prophet of god and could talk to saints. I worked as a offline support in a call center, I'm just answering agents questions and listening to calls. So one day we had a new guy, he told us he had schizophrenia and anxiety. I asked him what could we do in case he felt truly bad so I knew how to react  he said it was ok as long he took his meds. So one day he had two feedbacks and the supervisor left for a meeting,  he used to sit close to me as all new guys did and I saw him acting weird, he had trouble breathing normally, looked pale and started to laugh very hard when I asked him if he was right. My co-worked tried to ask him more but you know... most people don't know how to be helpful in that kind odd situations I didn't  want to touch him as I didn't know if that would trigger something but I just put my hand in his back when I saw him kinda faint. I told my coworker to give him some space and lead him to the nursery, didn't ask much, just asked for his locker keys, left him with the doc, gave him his stuff and told him he was free to go and I would take care of the rest at work. I think it was just a panic attack but after years of suffering attacks myself I learn that you don't need people telling you to be calm or that everything is going to be OK, you need sometimes rock solid and quick assistance without people getting their nose on your issue. They'll talk if they want to talk, my job was only to help him get better and resolve the issue I had the ability to resolve, not to act as a psychologist. He thank me a few days latter and I like to think he knew he could trust me.
