Good video
My best friend / roommate had schizophrenia and it really opens up your mind to what they are thinking or what they are going through. He would explain certain characters he has very regularly, the good and bad. And that affects him a ton, whether good or bad. And if you live with someone with it, the best way to go about it (that I have found out personally, everybody is different obviously) is distractions. Like that one person in the video said. But even some distractions made him uncomfortable, if it was music or shows. He would notice things off and get irritated. What people don't know is some people can go homeless with this if they are really deep into an episode. Because episodes don't just last a few minutes, they can literally be up to months.. it may not seem like an episode at the time but when it's over that clarity is shown. Also! The whole phone situation is so interesting because he did the same thing, or if he took a picture of something he was seeing he would send it to his gf and she would send the picture right back to him as he took it and he can see that it wasn't happening. One thing that we found useful is to have cameras around the apartment. Then if they are having a moment then we can look at the footage and they have that clarity moment. It can be very scary for them and everything that is happing is actually their reality. Just how we see everything is our reality. I really hope people watching this video kinda gets a feel of it and how serious it can be to certain people. And I still love him (as a brother) no matter what he is going through and am always doing my best to help him out as much as I can during episodes. They really just need supportive, understand and patient people around them. During episodes he would be very angry or annoyed towards me and you just take it with a grain of salt because he doesn't mean it, he's just extremely overwhelmed. (BTW I did ask him if I could talk about it and he is okay with this) there has been moments where he has been physically attacked by certain characters and had fought them back in self defense and thinking he killed a person but then we check the scene for evidence of it happening and there was none and that can affect them just as much as it happening in the moment. Cause that's a genuine memory they have. Just how going to work or school is to people without it. I hope people are more aware of this and start understanding ways to cope with it and push through as much as you can ‚ù§‚ù§‚ù§
I would love a video about ‚ÄúI spent a day with someone with bipolar disorder‚Äù because a lot of people have very strong misconceptions about bipolar.

The place she lives is gone and apparently nobody knows her, so he starts a trip all by himself to search for her. He is living with his brother and his brothers wife who is pregnant, so they‚Äôre really worried about him. Then he looses his pills and everything falls apart. He has hallucinations and stuff.   It was very complicated and exhausting to watch cause you didn‚Äôt know what was real and what was a hallucination and I can‚Äôt imagine what it is to actually have schizophrenia.

Especially when I hear people use derogatory phrases, I take the time to educate them on schizophrenia and ask them to stop using those words because it is very hurtful to those with schizophrenia and their family members who care deeply for them.

I am someone with phycosis. But it‚Äôs drug induced psychosis. I had a very seriously bad abusive child hood, which let me into taking drugs to escape reality, which unfortunately made everything worse. When I came off the drugs, about 3 weeks after I started to experience phycosis. I thought I had sold my soul to the devil 7 times, and that if I told anybody the devil would come and get me and kill me. It wasn‚Äôt until a few months later that I asked for help. By the time the help actually came, my phycosis had calmed down to a point I thought it was gone. It comes in waves, and different delusions and thoughts change, and manifest into something a heck of a lot more stressful, especially when I am around people. So I tend to stay alone in my flat. I am fascinated with this disorder.. I wish I can continuously forget it to learn about it again and again.. I don't know it is just something so interesting. Like I really loved how intriguing it is.. Don't get me wrong I don't want it to happen to anyone it is just that I am attracted to it in a really scientific-emotional way.
My brother has paranoid-schizophrenia, and watching this shows me just how much of a spectrum it is. I wish my brother was as high-functioning as these guests. They are blessed. With my brother, the only way I know how to compare it to is a death... who he was before he was officially/clinically diagnosed, and who is he became afterward. Comparing the two is like night and day, a completely different person. I used to cry about it often. Sometimes, because of the severity of his illness, I've thought of it as being worse than a death. Interacting with him is like a real life consistent reminder that he is gone. Once in a while, he will have a normal conversation for a few minutes and you'll get maybe a minute of who he used to be... but then 30 seconds later he says or does something that reminds you that he is mentally-ill. I've been in the grieving process for years and I think it's because of how difficult it is to simultaneously have him here physically, but completely gone mentally. I do praise God that he is the most innocent and pure-hearted person I know though. In a world where the average person may fear him out of ignorance, I at least have peace knowing he would never be the aggressor in any situation. Thank you guys for sharing your experiences.
Random interesting thing I learned about schizophrenia.. in some. other cultures, ppl with it weren‚Äôt demonized, and a lot of them are actually.. way happier and aren‚Äôt fearful of their hallucinations, compared to ppl with schizophrenia where it is demonized. Idk if it‚Äôs usually true or not, but if it is that might eventually lead to a way to help more ppl learn to live with it more easily.

I went to the hospital when I was young from stress. People noticed weird things. They kept it quiet and led me to a doctor.  There I found out I had a type of childhood schizophrenia from loss. I learned it wasnt a scary bad thing, it wasnt what people would say.(being 13 they would say bad things) but it took me so long to SEE schizophrenia, that I felt more unuseful, lost and unusual. My story couldnt help. Then I met someone and I learned mine was not like hers, and she needed proper care and service, so I clued in that you cant appropriate your problem on someone else. It was a learning experiance. That us why I appreciate your videos.

As someone with schizophrenia i like how you are judgements and understands
I don't know how to explain my own situations about this. Hell, I never really talk about it honestly because I'd feel judged--be told I'm just overreacting. Sometimes I believe that. Sometimes I don't. But, since I see others in the comment section are talking about theirs, I suppose it wouldn't hurt to speak too about it.  I was diagnosed with schizophrenia back when I was a senior in highschool. Idk how it came to be, or why it did, but it did. It all started during a time in class. And it involved my fellow students there. You see, how I experience it could be similar to others, or maybe not. But my thoughts felt different. I saw things that one probably wouldn't see or want to do. It was random, and it felt so real to me, as if I was doing the acts myself. They were horrible and violent, and just random. Then I realized I was sitting in the chair again with the class perfectly normal.   Then the thoughts continued, and currently where I am as a 21 year old, it happens even now. I simply had to close my eyes because I felt anxious from it. But yeah, I was diagnosed by my doctor after explaining how real these images were to me, and how they felt in detailed descriptions that involved inhumane acts.   But I still to this day wonder if it's really schizophrenia or something else. Regardless, they said that, and I just wanted to spill the beans without feeling judged as I would if I told my mom, or my brothers and sisters. Because they don't understand what I mean by this. So...yeah, hopefully you guys here can.

Oh boy, I just barely got through half of this one.  After having what I'm pretty sure was a panic attack from the auditory simulation, the visual ones started getting to me as well.  I'm sad I won't hear the rest of what they're saying, but christ, I can't do this right now. My brain is already conjuring up all sorts of stuff that I really don't need nor want. It feels like my senses are going into overdrive.  Yeah, this is not a good video for me.
I have hallucinations  as well, Visual, Auditory and touch/feeling. But according to my doctor I don't have schizophrenia because I have no delusions. I got the hallucinations and paranoia at times tho. But what my doctor doesn't understand is that I have had delusions at times, for example I was sure demons were after me, they wanted to hurt me, I sometimes don't recognize my own mirror image, as if I am seeing someone I never seen before etc.
One of these people seems to be faking it. Guess which one.
As someone who has recovered from Schizophrenia, I can tell that the key shift happened for me when I started to embrace my experiences and to question that perhaps the so-called delusions were real. That's when I started noticing that a lot of my experiences were actually really happening, even though some of them could not really be explained by "the experts". And after I learned that our perception of reality is largely based on our beliefs, I learned to re-construct and re-interpret my reality, basically by consciously altering my beliefs. I learned that you can simply let go of the belief because it no longer serves you. Most of those beliefs aren't even yours in the first place, but instead, it's something that was instilled in you by your family, school, society, or any other authority you assigned power to.

i remember before taking medication i would get really itchy on my body if i was not wearing a shirt. this went undiagnosed for years. i even joined the marine corps for 9 years until i was diagnosed. i am now 100% veteran disabled and ssdi. and i own a 585k house. these people seem they enjoy their hallucinations. i think it sucks.
So i don't know about the other people, but these videos are giving me new insight. Some of my friends and i have talk about when we hear voices, or see stuff that wasn't there. No we are not schizophrenic. But that is the point. It seems to me that people that have mental health problems are just people that have an excessive trait that we all already posses as human(and affects them way too negatively). We all have intrusive thoughs, but OCD people have them excessively. We all hear or see stuff that isn't there, specially when we are scare, but schizoprenic have them excessively.   If you think about it, we only need a minute to fathom just a bit how would it be to live like a person with a mental health disorder. No, we will not understand completely. But once we empathize and understand that it goes beyond those feelings that we can fathom, we can make live easier for them and remind them(and us) that they are exactly like us. Different hurdles in live no doubt, but we are the same, just trying to live.

My dad used to run a 711. He had to ban someone with schizophrenia because he often slipped on his medication, causing him to get aggressive very easily. One time while I was in the store, the guy (who I‚Äôll call Dave) was in too. You could tell by his body language that he was delusional, but relatively fine. As I‚Äôm at the till paying, Dave is behind me at the coffee island. My dad comes in and starts threatening to call the cops if he didn‚Äôt leave (this was a few years ago, I believe he said ‚ÄúDave, you know you can‚Äôt be in here. If you don‚Äôt leave I‚Äôm calling the cops‚Äù). My dads at the door, I‚Äôm at the till, and Dave is by the coffee. He starts getting aggressive, standing in a stance like he was ready to charge. One of my dads coworkers had already quietly called the police (I think the cops told my dads staff to call them if they could tell if he was off his meds, so they could try and get him back on them) so the cops were there within a couple of minutes. When we got back to the car, I turned to my dad (I think I was 14 at the time) and said ‚ÄúYou handled that VERY poorly. You don‚Äôt get aggressive with someone off their meds, ESPECIALLY with your daughter in middle of you two. Who knows what could‚Äôve happened if he charged.‚Äù And I think after me yelling at him about it, he never talked to him like that again

I was a kid , i didn't understand what my parents were going through when my older brother was diagnosed with schizophrenia. He became paranoid during his time in high school , he couldn't finish high school normally . he became violent towards us , threatening to poke my eyes out , he carried a bat and I remember him pacing bad and forth. My parents and I knew absolutely nothing about mental disorders and he would be extremely paranoid about our neighbors thinking they wanted to rape him. I remember him carving his wrist and talking / yelling at himself. It was scary but I was ignorant and mistreated him. Now as I type this I cry because it hurts to know I as his sister wasn't there for him when he needed me. He's on medication but he never leaves the house and hasn't in years , my parents suffered so much and my mom cried so many times. It was a nightmare when we knew nothing about this . he used to play with me as kids and now he's become a shell of what he used to be, hardly talks and my parents need to push him a bit to take care of himself. Before i moved out , I found his journal that he used to write in years ago and it hurt reading his thoughts and wanting to be accepted , to find someone to love him ...
thank you for giving such a good look at it because its really horrible and as someone with it im glad you can help others better understand it

What I find really sad about this is most of the time people only focus on the paranoid aspect of schizophrenia. Paranoid Schizophrenia isn't the only type. There is Disorganized Schizophrenie (sometimes considered even worse than the paranoid form) and Catatonic Schizophrenie (consisting of weird bodily function, like sitting or standing in weird positions for hours.) So no schizophrenie isn't all about hearing or seeing things. I have the disorganized form and I have no halluzinations (at least not visual or auditory, i have more like olfactory halluzinations). Right now everything is considered schizophrenia but there so many different forms.

Hiya, someone with psychosis, (and other things)  I have see, feel, hear, smell and taste hallucinations. (Yes, even taste and smell!!)  even though there are main components to schizophrenia and psychosis, there can and is things that vary for different people, such as I haven't met anyone that tastes or smells their hallucinations. Sometimes it tastes and smell like metals like iron or sulphur.  Other times it's like chamomile, Roses and other floral things.

Part 2: My friends personal experiences with Schyzoaffective Disorder. REMINDER AND DISCLAIMER: I have to put this so there is no confusion. These symptoms and experiences are to my froend personally. They do not reflect onto others with this disorder.  I will not be saying his name and only refering to him by gender or saying, "my friend". His halltinations are only 2 types on a constant when he has his "Bad days", and there is usually a third added of another. He usually hears and sees things and when a thirds thing is added it is either touch or smell. He is successfully on medications that work the best for him, however, even with this med, he still hears what he discribes as a thousand voices in the room whispering, however, it was not near as loud as that would actually be. He also on a more frequant that the wispers is shadows moving just out of eyesight in his periphery vision, the edge of what you can kind of see out of the corner of your eye when still looking forwards. Felt that need clarity. I'm not scared of how he acts if he has a bad day, to be honest, most of the tecnics to pull all of these people out of a spiral, a lot of them work on my friend. The one that works every time is not even giving the "thing" any attention. I only say thing because they can be qnything from a person to the Ghost Busters Movie Stay Puffed.

I don‚Äôt think I have schizophrenia. But in the past I‚Äôve seen weird shit from the corner of my eyes that were pretty realistic. Like most of it were glowing white figures just standing around watching me. Some had fancy dresses that were white or pink and sparkled. Didn‚Äôt see faces on em often. Like once saw a little girl with red paint on her face staring at me with a ripped dress and fangs. Usually they‚Äôd disappear when I looked at em directly cuz they were from the corners of my eyes. The scariest thing was a tall shadow-y figure with a peach-skin-toned face that was mushy/meaty with holes for eyes and a mouth staring at me. I looked at it directly but it didn‚Äôt disappear, it just moved before the doorframe. I started crying. Cuz when I saw those things I had to sleep alone in the living room. Most of the stuff I‚Äôd see was in afternoon/night so it most likely is from lack of sleep. One time in the middle of the night it was like I was transported away from my home and floating in space. Then I was back at home, laying on the couch.  I don‚Äôt really see stuff anymore, or at least I can‚Äôt tell if I do or if it‚Äôs just from my eyes seeing shit wrong cuz obviously when you see stuff from the corners of the eyes you can see stuff wrong, that‚Äôs normal. But these days I‚Äôm paranoid that I‚Äôm being watched. I‚Äôve always had a fear of being alone, I can only be alone if I have something distracting me. When I was younger I‚Äôd imagine an evil feminine voice laughing that something was gonna get me and I ran to a room where other people are there. Idk, again I don‚Äôt think I have schizophrenia, just wanted to share.
My dad had schizophrenia and he used to play as different characters for me when I was younger, I thought it was just him messing about but in the morning he‚Äôd never remember, I remember also he hallucinated an old man eating a bird alive.

I have talked to alot of people about my diagnosis and family and strangers are very curious about it. Because of all the misinformation, they wanna hear the truth. I love to answer peoples questions, but more fact than personal exsperience because of fear of triggering myself.   The only person whom has EVER judget me by my diagnosis was my primary doctor. When I was (finally!) brave enough to see my doctor by myself about feeling constantly sick for six month, he told me that the flu season just (!) started and was like "I see you have Schizophrenia. It's probably all in your head".   When I went into the car I started crying. Never in my life have I felt so degraded.   I know today that I was stressed out.

I have schizophrenia and it's nice to see people talking about it in a way that isn't shunning. :''). I get tactile, audio and visual hallucinations and delusions but now I just get random visuals every other month because I got lucky enough to not work and not go to school and live on disability with a support system.

In major therapy for a few years with one very good therapist discussing various disorders so that I could put some perspective on my own disorder, my therapist told me that the group of people she respects the most are people with schizophrenia because they suffer so much and try so hard to cope. My family was riddled with bipolar disorder and severe PTSD.  It was hard but not so hard as those with schizophrenia. My admiration for people is unsurmountable. And thank you for this episode.

This reminds me of a time a little while ago for some reason. I have a loft bed with a desk underneath, and one night I was scrolling on youtube super late, like always, when I see a weird blue light shining onto my ceiling. I couldn't see where it came from because the railing are completely solid, like a mini wall. I am frozen in fear and CANNOT move, wondering if there's aliens here or something. I finally muster up the courage to peek over the edge and see what it is, and guess what. It's my USB conversion thingy, and the screen that shows what's plugged into it and stuff is glowing blue. One of THE most terrifying/stupid experiences ever.
I have been having auditory hallucinations recently when I am super super tired.  It is so weird.  I don‚Äôt know if I am half-asleep or half dreaming when it happens because I am awake enough to experience it and sometimes respond audibly.  It‚Äôs so weird because most of the time I know it isn‚Äôt a real person right away and that the only possibility is that my mind is playing tricks on me, but I hear it loud and clear.  Sometimes it is a familiar voice, sometimes it isn‚Äôt, but it is loud and clear.  I couldn‚Äôt imagine feeling that way at all times.  It is so convincing and if I weren‚Äôt aware of my exact surroundings and my fatigue when it happens, there‚Äôs nothing that would immediately hint that it wasn‚Äôt real.   It must be incredibly difficult to live with at all times.  If you experience it just once you can begin to question what else your mind could conjure up and fool you into seeing, hearing, or believing.  Trippy.  I have a lot of respect and sympathy for anyone having to deal with schizophrenia, it has to be really confusing and difficult.

Cecilia was on an episode of Special Books by Special Kids. SBSK is another channel doing great work empowering the voices of people who are often overlooked and misunderstood. The creator, Chris Ulmer, interviews mostly children, sometimes adults, about their experiences living with various developmental disabilities, mental health problems, and neurodiversity. I think it is rare for special needs children especially to be given a platform to share their experiences, and I love that the internet makes it possible for creators like Anthony and Chris to give these people an audience to share their story with.

People aren‚Äôt crazy for having hallucinations. I mistake noises in movies or tv for my mom calling for me to do something and sometimes my room has nothing but white noise and the same thing happens. People take drugs to induce visual and auditory hallucinations and or distortions. It‚Äôs a chemical thing or genetic thing that affects people. Having schizophrenia is like having aids meaning it‚Äôs something that you have for the rest of your life but can be treated so that patients can live happy fulfilling lives even though they have some type of disorder. Obviously I‚Äôm generalizing one aspect and am in no way saying schizophrenia and aids are similar
Legit feel like most of the auditory hallucinations schizophrenic people hear are anxieties verbalized by a perceived personality that is also obviously a hallucination to outside people. Like when the guy gave an example of a tree saying I‚Äôm gonna fall on your and kill you was likely an extremely subconscious anxiety that most people wouldn‚Äôt even register but amped up by a chemical imbalance

i avoided this video for a while now, but i finally decided to watch it. the reason why is because since i was little i have had schizophrenia and later developed into schizoaffective depressive due to really traumatic events. schizophrenia is genetic in my family. i struggled with it all my life and have had several psychotic breaks and meltdowns along with visual and auditory hallucinations. i‚Äôm 17 and have been receiving medication for around a year now that works so well for me, and i have never felt this good before in my life. however, i don‚Äôt feel comfortable with that side of me, and i still somewhat shun it away out of shame and embarrassment. none of my friends know about my disorder, and the few times i have told friends in the past, they just brushed it off and invalidated my struggles. i know people won‚Äôt take me seriously if i tell them about my disorder, and i won‚Äôt be seen as a person anymore. it is so disheartening. so many people don‚Äôt think those with schizophrenia can lead full healthy lives, they just think we‚Äôre a bunch of rabid lunatics that belong in an asylum. i‚Äôve noticed that mental illnesses such as anxiety and depression have been receiving much awareness, and i hope that soon disorders like schizophrenia, BPD, and others become accepted and get to have that large platform of awareness that other mental illnesses get.

He loves his own reactions (which are often completely unnecessary and cringy). I wish I could like this, but ugh.
In medicine, we are taught that many signs of schizophrenia do not show up until mid to late twenties, but it's misconceptualized that children can be displaying these signs. It's not often that medical professionals realize what is happening in a child displaying these symptoms and treat them. I‚Äôve seen so many people, especially online fake schizophrenia/schizoaffective & it honestly is sad & rude. I‚Äôve suffered with schizophrenia since I was in the 5th grade, & now I‚Äôm in 11th, & almost done. I wasn‚Äôt diagnosed till just late last year, despite knowing I had it & struggled with it. Sadly I also can‚Äôt be medicated for it yet. When people say they wish they were schizophrenic it sucks, schizophrenia isn‚Äôt something to romanticize & isn‚Äôt fun or cool. It doesn‚Äôt make you a badass like a movie or tv show character (not that you cant be a badass & still have it obviously) I remember I had a huge episode where I kept having feelings & voices demanding me to do things or else I‚Äôd be stabbed or kidnapped (I still get those to this day; this is just a specific example) It got so bad that to get rid of it I fed into the delusion, which you shouldnt do. To cut the long story short I had gotten metal stuck in my bladder & had to get surgery to remove it. It was my first every surgery at the age of 15. (I‚Äôm 16, almost 17 now) Essentially what I‚Äôm trying to say is schizophrenia/schizoaffective disorder isn‚Äôt something that should be romanticized or thought of as cool. It can be a very tough thing to live with. To anyone out there who might have it, or does for sure, know that you are more than your mental disorders, you are more that what your head or others say about you. You & your opinions & experiences are completely valid. You are loved. üíô :}

wow.. this episode is so.. i cant even explain in words. my aunt was on the edge of a schizophrenic break. she constantly believed that my mom and our family were teaming up w/ her ex boyfriends to do something to her. i was only in middle school back then, so i didnt fully understand what was going on.. but it was still heartbreaking. i saw this person who i admired and loved since i was a kid slowly lose her personality, her happiness. she stopped smiling and would constantly be paranoid. my grandma made a VERY controversial decision and sent her to rehab for two years... without her consent (she did it in the phillipines thats why she had full control over her). after talking with my aunt once she came back, my mom, and the people surrounding my aunt.. i started to realize the stigma against people w/ schizophrenia. a month after my aunt came back, i was sent to the psych ward (for personal reasons i will not discuss). there i met someone who was either schizophrenic and didn't know it, or was and was trying to deny it. she wasnt this "crazy, loud, violent" person.. she was just like me. obviously in a really bad mindset and a really bad environment. im glad u made this video to help the de-stigmatization of schizophrenia and just mental health overall. thank you anthony :)

the most interesting thing about schizophrenia (and i have just started the video so I don't know if Anthony addresses this) is that sociocentricity, individualism, and collectivism greatly affected symptoms and for sufferers where family was more important they interpreted auditory hallucinations as ancestors giving them guidance as opposed to negative voices commanding them towards misdeeds which occurred in more individualistic societies. edit: he just stuck to people from NA, which is fine, but it is interesting that other cultures treat this condition differently.

Jorge might have DID too. I got the warning sign from him talking about being different people
Basically... schizophrenia is when you have to deal with EXTERNAL entities, while DID is when you have to deal with INTERNAL entities. The first, other people/things bug you, the other you have other sides of you that have a life of their own and influence you. They look like quite opposite, more than likely. I don't know how people can mix them up......  That said, HANG IN THERE, GUYS! We are cheering for you.

Do you think you‚Äôd ever be interested in interviewing people with ADD/ADHD?   I know a lot of people have it and it‚Äôs not really stigmatized or controversial, but a lot of people also think it‚Äôs just ‚Äúoh they have crackhead energy‚Äù or just a issue with focusing when it actually has a lot of side affects no one ever talks about such as: -rejection sensitive dysphoria -object permanence issues  -memory loss -executive dysfunction  -mood swings  Like for example, sometimes I‚Äôll forget to talk to people if I don‚Äôt see them everyday. I‚Äôll even forget to talk to people I‚Äôm dating because of the object permanence issue.  Or with the rejection sensitive dysphoria someone will say to me ‚Äúhey It‚Äôs no big deal but it kinda hurt when you said xyz‚Äù which is something that‚Äôs healthy and normal, but my brain immediately jumps to ‚Äúoh my god I‚Äôm a terrible person why would I think it was okay to say that to them I‚Äôm the worst person on this planet, I don‚Äôt deserve to live‚Äù   I didn‚Äôt mean to ramble, but growing up I didn‚Äôt know a lot of the things I did were from my ADD, and I spent a big chunk of my teenage years thinking I was a terrible person because ‚Äúif I cared I wouldn‚Äôt do those things‚Äù I think it‚Äôd be really helpful for people to know it‚Äôs more than just not being able to focus, especially for younger people with ADD because despite being diagnosed when I was 12 NO ONE warned me about these things, not even my doctors!
My uncle has schizophrenia and because of that he has of course his ups and downs, that‚Äôs why I haven‚Äôt seen him in two yearsüò≠

I‚Äôve grown up with 4 family members living with schizophrenia.  Dealt with every possible type and have my little brother that does very well handling it now.  But when it started when he was 21, it threw us all for a loop.  With so many types already around us daily, including my mother, my little brother hit me strangely for some reason.  He wasn‚Äôt on medication in the beginning and was it was difficult to know how to deal with him.  My mother and other family members all had homes where people took care of them.  My little brother was living with his girlfriend who just became pregnant when he broke.  I had to have therapy myself because I started to become afraid of dealing with the bad things he had going on and worried about myself and something happening to me.  I hated those years of my life.  Today, my brother knows what‚Äôs happening and how to take care of himself.  He lives alone now when years ago, he couldn‚Äôt be left alone without him going out and doing something that risked his life.  I felt like I was always waiting for that call.  Schizophrenia was a torment to me because it kept me afraid all the time.  Today, with the help of therapy, I‚Äôm better too.  It was strange being around so many schizophrenic people in my life for ax far back as I can remember.  Starting with my mother as a child and ending with the baby brother.

PSA: don‚Äôt do drugs kids. Or at the very least be safe. The second time I ever had mushrooms was a bad time where I legitimately believed I was being possessed and had died. I have had a couple episodes of (I suppose PTSD) that came close with some of theses descriptions, namely the paranoia and perception of being able to read minds. Seems a lot funnier in hindsight but it‚Äôs scary going through that perception of being in a time loop. Drugs can do great things in the field of medicine but you just have to be careful.

There are also people in this industry that are just in it for the money and a light needs to be shined on this issue. I have a really active imagination, always had.  When I was younger  and at a time in my life when I felt lost I started experiencing derealization and exploded my imagination to the max, to the point where  would hear people when I was half asleep. I was depressed and started living in my head. I must've been acting really different because  I remember  the school psychologist calling me to her office and warning me, telling me that if I didn't change my behavior I could develop schizophrenia and I was terrified.  that moment grounded me a lot. but now I realize how wrong that was. I decided to shut my imagination for a while and abandon the things  had created in my head. Years later I'm not fearful anymore. I still experience a lot of derealization and live in my head, but it feels a lot better because I'm at a better place.

love the eric andre reference
I have not been diagnosed so in no way am I saying I have Schizophrenia. I'm just here to talk about my experiences.  I've had hallucinations my entire life, auditory and visual. It started when I was about 5, I'd have conversations with trees, rocks, inanimate objects like jackets and pencils. Stuff would just talk to me. I'd see and hear creatures and I identified them as fairies/dragons/elementals since I didn't know what else to call them. But as I got older things got really dark and scary after the age of 10, I started seeing/hearing people, monsters, shadows, and animals that weren't there. I couldn't sleep because these monsters and shadow people would keep me up or wake me up. They would say things like they wanted to eat me or take me away from my family and reach out and start grabbing at me. Or they'd tell me that everyone I loved was going to die a horrible painful death, or that the world was going to end in my life time. Or how no one loved me or would miss me if I died. I started having sleep paralysis and night terrors at this time too. In my mid teens, between 15-17 in particular, I went through what I like to call the gore phase. One hallucination in particular was just blood vision, everything would be covered in blood, and I mean everything. Me, my friends, and the walls and floors (kinda like that scene from "War of the Wars"). I'd hear the blood dripping down and flowing from inside things. The creatures I'd see would be mangled and missing limbs, writhing on the ground or hanging from the walls and ceilings. On tame days, there'd be no blood but severed body parts in certain places, like when at lunch there'd just be a hand on the table or a severed leg propped up against a wall (there were never any heads though, which I'm thankful for). I would also see a herd of giant red butterfly's in the sky in the morning while going to school. Also, during this time period I didn't know if I was asleep or awake, I've always been a person with extremely vivid dreams so nothing felt real and I couldn't tell what was hallucinations, reality, or if I was just dreaming. I would constantly mistake voices from people actually talking to me which made a lot of weird situations. There were times I didn't know who I was or who other people were and I was just scared of everything and I didn't trust my surroundings. On the flip side, I have a group of voices who I call my sisters, they are very helpful and comforting. These particular voices helped me get through my depression and suicidal tendencies and were my main emotional support system, they are still with me to this day. I also have a little animal companion, a little blue bird who sits on my shoulder and sings and talks to me. One of my "imaginary friends" from child hood is still with me as well even though I can no longer see them I can hear them and know where they are in the room.    Living with these experiences is something that I've gotten so use to that it is normal, I have a much better grasp of reality now as an adult. I have a better time identifying what is and isn't real after years of finding cooping mechanisms and understanding triggers that cause these extreme episodes of hallucinations.

We need to treat them with respect the world they live in can be really scary and we should understand not judge

I think about Etika on a day to day basis. My brother has bipolar disorder and has gone through some very heavy manic episodes that have been quite scary. And when I saw Etika go through his mania, that was utterly heartbreaking. His final video haunts me to this day, because the depression that hits after a manic episode is so intense. I'd argue they are more scary than the manic episode itself. I'm glad it was brought up though, because I really do not want Etika to ever be forgotten. The way he was convinced nobody was going to remember him, or care .. he couldn't have been more wrong.
I suffer from extreme social anxiety & generalized anxiety and often I feel like what I'm living isn't reality and that I'm actually somewhere else right now acting as if I was here. A lot of times this thought slips into my mind and tells me that the only way to get back to my reality, my actual life is to end this life. This alone makes me feel hopeless and crazy, but to know that some people suffer from that on top of many other things is really amazing. Like, these people are so strong for pushing through despite all of these things happening to them, I'm really amazed and proud.

can you do a video about bipolar disorder? there's a lot of misconceptions about it, especially about bipolar 2 disorder and people thinking it can't have the same life-ruining consequences bipolar 1 has -- cuz they're both just as debilitating, and even cyclothymia. i think this is something a lot of people would relate to and could get educated about thoroughly, as everyone seems to just think bipolar is super fast mood swings!
Gosh I feel for the hat guy.  I had desrealization because of my anxiety and it feels so much like that. I hate it so much because I feel like nothing around me is real. I feel like I am in a comma or in a dream and I need to wake up. Doesn't help that the more I think about my future is worse. You suddenly start realizing that you are alive, that you sleep, you breath, you eat, you speak, you think about the things you say before saying it in a matter of seconds. What happened 2 seconds ago is now the past and that the present is short. That when you grow up you'll have a house, you'll work, you'll have a routine, you'll have a lover, you'll have children, you'll bring live to this earth. Not only that, but I also start realizing that there's other people around me, are they real? How do they see stuff? How do they live? How do they think? How do they experience life? They've  had sex, they eat, they sleep, they breath. And when all of these thoughts combine your breathing will stop knowing that one day you'll die. My breathing stops for a second and when I feel alive I feel wrong! I feel wrong when I'm alive and I used to cry because I wanted to get out of this state. Like a desperation. The thing about desrealization is that its caused by massive levels of anxiety, like a defense mechanism, but it'll bring you more anxiety because you're gonna constantly want to get out of it. There is no precise time that someone can tell you when it ends and it freaks me out. This makes me start thinking of: will I forever be like this?, will it feel like a dream whenever I go to new places?. This brings me insomnia sometimes and when I wake up it feels weird. It comes to the point where you want to get out of your own skin. Anyone who had watch JoJo part 5, when Giorno hits Bruno and Bruno sees himself in third person. That's what I sometimes want and what I used to feel like. Its horrible. At least thays the best way I can describe it.  And I thought the same as him, I thought that if i somehow kill myself I will get out of here, but I push thay thought aside. Not only because this is REAL this is REAL LIFE, but also because I dont want to end this life if its real. I love my mom, my family, my friend. I dont want it to end if its real. I also push it aside because I don't want to wait until natural death to know if I am real or not. I want to enjoy this life as much as I can.

When I was younger at age 13  I had a psychosis. My doctor prescribes me the wrong medication ( at the time she didn‚Äôt know I was sensitive to medication), my adolescent life changed completely. At first when I was at the beginning of taking my new meds I felt a strange desire to clean everything I could just to relive the energy I had. I knew I wasn‚Äôt feeling like myself!!! I would withdraw from the world more so than usual. I felt scared for myself and others around me, I didn‚Äôt feel safe. It got too the point wear a 13 year old girl would cry to her mother to hide all the knives and anything that could cut myself with or others. That when my parents realized I was not in my right mindset. I was already slow to beginning with but it keeps getting worse. Finally I show more and more symptoms. That when I had my first panic attack! My parent know what to do I was rushed to the hospital, while my doctor was on the phone with me! My mother arrived at the hospital intently the nurses see me and I don‚Äôt even wait. A body guard comes with us to make sure I‚Äôm okay and to protect me from myself. There‚Äôs a blank for the rest of this moment. I think it‚Äôs due to the panic attacks ( literally feels like you are dying) I remember seeing a needle in my arm with water like liquid pouring into my vains. I felt the pain of the needle and stared at my arm for a few minutes. I see a man barging in with a bunch of medical staff. I swear he was having a heart attack !!!! Then I past out. Then opening my eyes i realized it was not the same hospital mom told me they had to change because the other hospital didn‚Äôt have a child‚Äôs Psych ward.  I‚Äôm up stairs and see that the we arrived at the 5th floor I was scared and happy at the same time best I have never been so confused my whole life! The psychologist ask me many questions and it seem I hear voices I see hallucinations of me hurting people I love and my self and it a female voice that telling me to do those nasty thing I remember my emotions were all over the place I would be angry then sad and then really happy it was so hard to control. I felt like I was never going to get better. Few months past every day they would be sticking a needle twice a day to study me because I was a rear case I was getting better little by little but they didn‚Äôt even understand why my mind when off and then just healed after year like if I never had schizophrenia of DPL and high anxiety and mild depression. I felt weak from years I would be so slow and I wouldn‚Äôt make many friends. Here one thing positive I became smarter than a lot of people in my class I was getting the grade I could never get before. It like this happened for a reason so that I would believe in myself more and be able to go to college and university and do a career in a music profession. Music did save me I‚Äôm proud to be a musician. I figure music block all the insanity I was feeling and took away in a beautiful bliss of happiness. But if I‚Äôm going to be completely honestly I think I still am a little schizophrenic but it‚Äôs as real as the speaker in the video! I guess it because it was more of a psychosis than having the to deal with this all time. For me it‚Äôs little hallucinations and few times a week I hear conversations like in the kitchen even though I know there know one. thanks for the Information. It helped me come out with my story. And I won‚Äôt write my whole story because it would be a big chunk of my life so yeah thank you so much and godbless you all and if you don‚Äôt believe I wish you positivity and kindness

I have schizophrenia and it's so demonized to the point where I've been mistreated and abused in my work place and college for it.

My dad has PTSD do to being in the army. He had multiple mental breakdowns, and delusions. That luckily means that I learned about a lot of mental disabilities at a young age.
My mother developed schizoaffective disorder in her 40s while I was in my last year of middle school.  She started to develop symptoms shortly after starting a new job and she had auditory hallucinations and delusions.  She believed that her coworkers were out to harm her and her family.  It was absolutely heartbreaking to witness her going through that.  Imagine someone you care deeply for slowly begin to lose themselves.  Any humor they had, their personality just stops coming through and all you see is fear and paranoia.  That is what my mom was experiencing and my heart still aches imagining how it was for her.  She fully believed in these delusions and to her point of view, she had no one to believe her.  Can you imagine?  You fully believe there are people trying to harm you and you have NO ONE who believes you and no one to help you.  Imagine the helplessness and despair she must have been feeling.  We could all see the very real fear she was experiencing for herself and her family and she pleaded with us to believe her.  We pleaded with her to seek out therapy and psychiatric help.  And for a long time, she wouldn't.  Her delusions eventually lead her to believe that her family wasn't actually her family, but people disguised as her family and we got into many a hairy situation because of that.  She got into some legal trouble due to her disorder and it all culminated a few years ago.  She either had to seek psychiatric help or she would go to jail for a year.  The circumstances leading up to that point are a little complicated, but the legal system had failed us before when it came to my mother and we all felt betrayed.  But it was the push that got my mom on the right track.  She was diagnosed and got on medication.  While medication helps curb symptoms for a lot of people with schizophrenia/schizoaffective disorder, medication completely erased my mom's symptoms.  Her personality shines through now and she no longer experiences daily fear or paranoia.  And I am so happy that her mental illness no longer drives her life.  I'm so glad that she can be happy again.

It's really cool to see Cecilia on this episode of "I spent a day with"! I had a class with her my first semester of college, and she was the first person I met who had schizophrenia. She did a class advocacy project on schizophrenia, and she really opened my eyes about it. Typical media representation is highly negative and misleading, and I'll admit that I was very ignorant about schizophrenia beforehand. That's why it is so important to learn about disorders/diseases/etc from first-hand accounts (like this video or organizations made by people with said condition), because it makes them more "real" or normalized than misleading media portrayal or even just reading scientific definitions and symptoms. You see the people first.  Anyways, I'm glad to see that Anthony provided this platform to educate even more people about this topic. I hope Cecilia is doing well and she continues to reach more people through opportunities like this!

Cody pointed something out that's really important.  I have DID and for a long time I assumed I was schizophrenic and even doctors suggested I was schizophrenic because I talked about the voices in my head and they assumed it was auditory hallucinations.  I never knew that auditory hallucinations were OUTSIDE the mind like physically hearing something. For me the alters in my system are like my thoughts they're inside. I dont hear them literally.  But because no one talks about that distinction I didnt know about DID for a really long time. (Also the doctors didn't diagnose me with schizophrenia either because I didnt have any of the symptoms. They just gave me the diagnosis of "psychosis")

you should interview people with HPPD
I‚Äôve believe I possibly could have schizophrenia but I also have phobias that are based on my paranoia (specifically the fear of broadcast warnings and amber alerts). When I turn my TV off, keep it on without my xbox being on, or keep my tv on the silent xbox Home Screen, I suddenly get huge paranoia that a demon will pop up on my screen suddenly with a jarring scream, or that a broadcast warning will suddenly appear. I live in Las Vegas so the last time we had a warning was a radio test so there‚Äôs little to no chance of one popping up anyways. Or the common fear of a demon being behind you in the dark when walking through a hall or going up or down the stairs, but I suddenly imagine a demon charging at me without moving limbs at a 1000 mph to go up to my face like FNAF on crack. I have past trauma as well which could be possibly another reason for these paranoias. But nonetheless I wasn‚Äôt diagnosed with Schizophrenia with my recent tests. I've been living my entire life with a schizofrenic family member. He's a very nice and kind guy, just having anxiety and paranoia. But whenever he was delusional or paranoid, like thinking we want to poison him etc., majority of the family would just tell him off, like "yeah whatever, just stop with this bullshit already", like he was just in a mood and not having a fairly serious condition. Everyone knew he had schizophrenia, but they never tried to understand him and expected him to behave as if he didn't have it. Same went for me, I have Asperger's syndrome and whenever I was behaving autistic I would be told to "stop acting autistic and just behave normally". Like excuse me, but asking a mentally ill person to behave normally is like asking someone to stop breathing - they can try for a while, but eventually they will start breathing again, whether they want to or not.

I think it would be cool if you did one of these on OCD. There are MANY different types of OCD and they present differently in every person. I think when most people think of OCD they only think of cleaning OCD or checking OCD, but like many mental illnesses (including  schizophrenia, as I learned from this video!) it is a spectrum and each person's experience is wildly different. For example, I have what is known as "magical thinking OCD," which is nothing at all like what people might think of when they think of OCD. There are just so many misconceptions and it is so little understood by the general public, which can be pretty isolating and disheartening. Would love to see some light shed on it! That aside, this video was awesome, as are all of your videos. I always look forward to learning something new from them :)

This has me really questioning my childhood.... I had "an over-active imagination" that was highly visual and not in my control. It scared the piss out of me almost every night until I was a teen. I think I was halfway between believing there were actually monsters there, and not believing it. The visuals were glitchy and inconsistent, and they clearly made no logical sense, but I did not have the strength to dismiss them and ignore them. There was always at least one monster under my bed, one outside the window, one in the closet, and one outside the door, every night. I could barely move, I didn't want to attract attention. This happened up until I was about 15 or so, I didn't want to mention it to my parents because I knew socially I should have been done with nightmares, fear of the dark, and imaginary friends a long time ago. I "just dealt with it". (By hiding for years.) Eventually, as an adult, I did got psychotic symptoms noted on my mental health record, because of the most mundane hallucination... I can sometimes hear music playing, and when I hunt down the source, there's nothing there. If it were like a stranger's voice coming from nothing, maybe I would be able to tell it from reality through logical deduction alone like I did with the monsters, but the phantom music (ringtones, gameboy music, orchestra over the radio, edm through headphones)... it was too real, too normal, too plausible. So I wonder... Is there really a difference between the music and the monsters? Were they ALL hallucinations?
I admire them if I had schizophrenia. It would suck. I would go crazy hearing voices and seeing stuff

I'm not diagnosed schizophrenic but I noticed they all mentioned shadow people and that's something I used to see as a kid up until I was maybe 10 among some other things. I've mentioned this to therapists I've had and none of them even the one I have now have any clue as to what was or is possibly going on with me. Maybe 90% of the things that I experienced at the time I haven't experienced since I was 15 and now that I'm 25 I honestly feel so alone cause I talk about the things I've experienced or experience and it's usually treated like well "I don't know what that is but you seem fine" Anyway, I guess I was just wondering if that was normal or if anyone else had experienced anything like this. I wish love to everyone and I'm not trying to diagnose myself or hurt anyone.

Thank you for making this video. I know I was one of those who requested it! I lived with trauma-induced psychosis(that got misdiagnosed as schizophrenia) for ten years, and would have both auditorial, visual, olfatory and tactile hallucinations.  I heard voices for ten years, and I do remember the first time, I coukd hear a woman screaming, like a blood curdling scream. Later started the static voices that then became clear, and they told me that if I'd do as they said they'd take the pain away(I was already depressed and had lots of traumas in my childhood). I too thought I was posessed at first, because I was a kid(like 12/13) and I didn't know any better explanation. My whole teen years was a nightmare, literally.  Then got misdiagnosed whenI turned 18 and moved to an adult psych unit, and lived with thinkng I had schizophrenia for four years, and the worst thing about it(except for living in a nightmare) was people's misconceptions! I had people literally back away from me when I told them I was schizophrenic.  But one day, it was weirdly quiet all of a sudden(Imagine hearing voices for ten years then suddenly it's all quiet, so weird) and I realized something was wrong? Schizophrenia doesn't just go away? So I went to a new psych unit and asked for a full investigation, all tests they had, just to get this straight once and for all. And it turns out I have depression, GAD, PTSD, eating disorder and autism, and all of those things mixed with a lot of trauma I never  processed contributed to a trauma induced psychosis.   The mind is weird. It's like "Oh, so you feel like shit, here, have another realtiy that is also shit!"
I‚Äôm currently studying psychology and have multiple people in my life who have mental health disorders and so I‚Äôm incredibly grateful to Anthony for helping to educate people and help get diminish the misinformation that is out there . So thank you Anthony. üòä
I was diagnosed with unspecified schizophrenia and unspecified psychosis  last year (I was 13). My psychiatrist that I had at my dad's house (when I was there) thinks it could possibly be a brain tumor. Now I'm scared that it might be a brain tumor. üò∞

Just want to share this story...  The son of one of my neighbours has shizophrenia he sees horrible things (he also painted) and is even in a mental hospital. A few years ago he erupted twice the hospital and hided somewere at my home. So I live in an apartment building with a quite big front garden and a lot of trees and bush and it was a bit scary to know there is a person wich is scared to hell and you don't know were he is or how he sees you and you come home at night. Even the police were looking for him for many days. The thing is he is just a normal person but a frightened person is unpredictable. It later turned out he was hiding in the basement (the basement is really scary i'm not joking!) And lit a fire there because it was cold(that was dangerous cause of the gas pipes). I'm really sorry for him :( because this must be/been terrible for him and i wish him the best and hope he's doing good. And of course for everybody else who struggles with schizophrenia or something else. Thank you for you time and have a nice day :) PS. Sorry for my bad English
I've been struggling with the fact that I might have schizophrenia for the last 9 years. I need help and I'm afraid to actually go get the diagnosis. I'm a mother of two and got sober 9 years ago and haven't looked back but I've had alot of trauma throughout my life and I always knew I was different. After getting clean I realized that the freak out moments that I had while I was using were not completely due to what I was on. I've been with the same man for 7 years and I'm pushing him away with getting paranoid he's doing something, hearing him talk badly about me, and I've even convinced myself he would sleep with someone while I was on the phone with him. I'm scared to say anything. Plus with covid going on my dad died and his dad got sick so we have been living 4 hours apart. He has our son and I have my daughter. He just got an apartment for all of us after a year and now I can't go out there until I have a job set in stone. I haven't seen them in 6 months and I just want to be there. I'm planning on telling him when we are all there and together already. I'm really scared and don't know what to do.

My heart goes out to them, that has to be so frustrating and sometimes terrifying to have hallucinations like that. Technology seems to have been a wonderful tool for the one gentleman. It's so very important to get a diagnosis when dealing with something like schizophrenia and schizo effective disorder. It not only helps the individual dealing with it, but also their social circle as well. When my sons father started hallucinating his dead wife, he finally got help and medication and it helped him immensely and helped his relationships as well. Unfortunately, he didnt have insurance and no longer had medication, I believe his gf pushed him to the edge and we lost him to suicide a bit over a year ago. Its soooooo important to reach out to a trusted loved one when you're having a hard time. I send them all nothing but light, love, and positivity. I pray that we all reach out to each other, love one another and treat others the way you wish others to treat you.

I'm glad you did this video about Schizophrenia and this is the reason why I'm writing my comment asking you to maybe consider doing a "I spent a day with" about ADHD because some people tend to confuse it w/ Schizophrenia (mainly cause ADHD can cause hallucinations sometimes even when being treated)  and/or Anxiety (since many symptoms between ADHD and anxiety overlap). Not only that but also because there are way too many people that are like "oh your kid isn't paying attention in class therefore they have AD(H)D" when it isn't the case. Always love your videos, Anthony! You do an amazing job with these interviews and allowing the people you feature to express themselves in an authentic, candid way.   I was wondering if you might be interested in doing a video on PTSD and CPTSD, perhaps comparing and contrasting the two? There is still a significant amount of stigma surrounding CPTSD because it is a commonly misunderstood disorder. In a nutshell, CPTSD results from repeated trauma experienced over an extensive period of time, rather than a singular traumatic event (wherein PTSD develops).   It can be extremely difficult for those suffering from CPTSD, as well as therapists, to distinguish the symptoms from other trauma-related disorders such as PTSD, Borderline Personality Disorder, and Bipolar Disorder. As a result, patients with CPTSD are often misdiagnosed and overlooked.   I think this would be a really interesting topic to explore, as well as one that deserves more attention in general. It would also resonate with me on a personal level, since I have recently been diagnosed with CPTSD. Anyway, thanks to anyone who took the time to read all this :) <3

So I have a story, last year i had to go to the hospital for my depression and anxiety and there was this girl named Ariel, that was my roommate in the hospital and she did have schizophrenia and depression, but she was a good person and didn't let it bring her down and i looked up to her for that and after a few days of being friends she told me this and I've never met anyone that had it, I know what it is and what it does to people, but honestly my first thought was whoa that's cool, I'm sorry if that is offensive but that's what i thought so I told her that and she seemed happy that I was accepting her and she told me about her life and I told her mine and we because best friends. We had these like classes during the day and during the night or break time I would ask her if she's seen anything and she would tell me about it and I would be positive about it and we would joke about it to make her feel more better and she was there for me too, when I would have my panic attacks she would hug me, even tho she wasn't aloud to and told me It's ok and tells me what I need to hear, I was there for her and she was there for me. We were there for week but I felt like I knew her forever and sadly she didn't have a phone and her parents were really strict. I have never forgotten her and I miss her everyday, she was the best person I have ever met, even with her difference, so no matter what their differences, it's their personality that counts

He's not only super respectful and open-minded, (which should be normal human behavior and should be normalized, not something to be amazed at) but he also knows perfectly how to be completely serious about something, yet still realize when it's okay to laugh or joke around to make his guests feel comfortable and not like they are in a test to just answer questions because they aren't humans that can talk about their situation or that they are victims to feel pity for. It makes them feel like they're just talking to a friend, but while still maintaining the respectful boundaries of interviewer-interviewed. This video terrified me. I didn't realize how close to schizophrenia I was... I've just been thinking "that's obviously not there" or "I'm not hearing that" just because I know that its not there its crazy that I just let this be normal. I just chalked it up to my mind playing tricks on me.   Sometimes  I off handly confirm with someone to see if something was real and I would often drag my mom or dad to my room to look at the giant bugs that I clearly saw and they didn't as a child.  There was a blob in my TV. That if I started too long would take shape.  Even now I constantly see a dog and when I observe that its not my actual dog, I dismissed it. I would just look away. Or blare my music so loud I couldn't hear any weird noises or voices that no one else could hear.  I didn't even realize how big of a space it took in my life.  Thank you for the information this helped a lot and I will be looking into this more.

First of all, thank you for making this video!!!!    I'm so glad you brought this up, because Schizophrenia is something that I feel people need to learn more about‚ù§ My mum got diagnosed with schizophrenia approximately 6 years ago. I was around 10 when she started to become really sick, but I didn't know what to believe. She told me she was completely fine, but I could tell something was off. She'd randomly go outside, talk to herself, nod, pick up sticks, lay on the grass etc. She still does some of those things, but it's definitely better now than it was a couple of years ago. She had to be in a mental hospital for 2 months, where she got medical help, but she has never "admitted" she's sick.  It's really difficult dealing with it. To me, it's the fact that she'll never be what she used to be, that really breaks my heart. I have dreams about her "normal" self sometimes, and I cry when I wake up. It sucks, but she's still my mum. She's human, just like everyone else.  Schizophrenia is a very misunderstood illness, but having someone close to me diagnosed with it, makes me able to have a different perspective on mental health issues and how to handle people dealing with them!! This video really shows the individuality of it. Schizophrenia is really complex since everyone's minds are different (past experiences, trauma, relationships etc) but I think you did a great job on finding people who differ from each other:))üíï

Anthony, you're literally changing the world for the better with this series, thank you so so much. The way it's edited is entertaining and captivating, yet the information packed inside is so vital and valuable for people to know. I'm a psychology major student, and I have a close friend with schizophrenia. It's really incredibly misunderstood in society, especially where we live, starting from the way it's constantly mentioned in our classes as an example for pretty much everything, and ending with the difficult journey of self‚Äìunderstanding that my friend went through. From an outside perspective, it was very difficult not knowing how to help other than give him contacts of qualified professionals; especially when he received the diagnosis, but couldn't accept or come to terms with it, saying "I have the worst disorder in history". It took a lot of time. (He has now successfully found medication that works for him and is doing very well) I'm glad everything settled. Thank you for contributing to ending the stigma

I think it's a funny idea that when talking about schizophrenia Anthony is just talking to himself like there was someone there
My mother & father both have schizophrenia, they met in a hospital, I was taken away at birth as my mother can be quite violent, my father is not really good at looking after himself and has been living in assisted living for the majority of his life(they are in their 60s now). I am glad there are those out there with the disorder that can have a somewhat normal life but this isn't the case for everyone. My mother is still violent on a regular basis, my father is pretty jumbled with his speech and its hard to follow a conversation. My mother and father both rely like Jorge on lots of sounds to drown out the voices. I worry that my younger brother is developing symptoms(that's right they had another child, who also was put into adoption, we didn't grow up in the same family), although I have suggested this he is sure he doesn't need help. I myself am in therapy for anxiety & depression but given what my family's mental health history is, my therapist is always looking out for things out of the ordinary. I really appreciate this episode in particular to know what it can be like for some people with the disorder, I¬¥ve never been able to understand from my parents. Thank you Anthony. Mental health education is as important as physical health.

I used to have the audible voices from 2012 to 2016 when I was in a very stressed and depressed time. the voices can be super accurate to a situation too, like you will hear it coming from a specific room or place in the correct way it would sound. Also the whispers or inside voices, they would say things not just invetween your thoughts but on top of your thoughts and that freaked me out because that‚Äôs when I started believing it wasn‚Äôt just me being schizo since it was really odd to hear two words or sentences in two complete different voices in my mind layered and understandable. Oh I also thought I was being watched by everyone in my life like if it was a secret tv show.  It went away after I learned to not be paranoid all the time and moved away from my old life. And stoped smoking pot and drinking as well. I felt like the alcohol was making my gut suffer and was not getting vitamins in my system, I took a blood test and I was deficient in vitamin D witch caused paranoia, I tried d2 but it gave me a panic attack but D3 works. Good luck to anyone out there living with this

I remember in like, elementary school, I would make up characters and I'd talk to them instead of other people. Some people said it was just a phase and childish stuff, but they never really went away. My characters were most often kind to me though, so I never brought it up with anyone, I just kept it all in, until one day in middle school after my grandpa died, and there was a new voice that said I was a waste of space and that I was a terrible person for not being more upset about his death(I was grieving for a few months after his death). Although Van[the bad guy] was trying to make me more upset, he did teach me to value the lives of others more, and I'm very grateful that I don't have hallucinations of demons or monsters, and just friends. I'm not sure how I would diagnose this, I've been diagnosed with ASD and anxiety, and they've pretty much ruled out a schizophrenia diagnosis, but hearing all of this makes me question it all.

My uncle has schizophrenia. He's had it since he was 20 years old. He is one of the nicest people I know and one of the most generous. Growing up, I was extremely close to him. He now lives on his own, and generally choses to be by himself, except for when he goes to group once a week. What Kody said about schizophrenic people being more of a danger to themselves, than others is more than accurate. They are still people, and they still feel just like any other person. It can be such an isolating mental disorder, and I wish these kind of things were taught earlier on. If it wasn't for my prior experience with my uncle, and taking multitudes of psychology classes, especially abnormal psych, I would not have the knowledge I do now. I have a great amount of empathy for people that struggle with shizophrenia, because it can be terrifying. However, it isn't life ending.

This is one of the many reasons I'm so angry when movies and video games use mental illnesses such as DID or schizophrenia or many others as a horror factor. Like look at how abnormal and scary these people with these conditions are, like that's the worst enemy, the biggest horror they can think of. When in reality people with these debilitating disorders when left untreated and misdiagnosed are usually the ones to live their lives mistreated and afraid. I'm not saying you cannot make movies or shows or games about these conditions but with it comes a huge responsibility to NOT contribute to the stigma already surrounding such a vulnerable group of people.  I also appreciate that Anthony didn't say wondrous world of schizophrenia. In many cases that expression helps make a serious topic more lighthearted, helps normalising it in people's eyes but I don't think anybody with the actual condition finds anything wondrous about it and sometimes that just has to be accepted. It is however great to see that people with such a terrifying condition can find a way to live good lives as so many people can't actually imagine a future for themselves when they're hit with a diagnosis like this.

omg that poor women she seems so sweet and she goes through such torment. I feel so bad for her because my mom who was schizo effective (which is schizophrenia and bipolar mixed together) committed suicide 4 months ago and it's been hard and I just imagine that poor sweet lady snapping from the stress and it tears at my heart. she had major delusions of being the reborn Isis (an Egyptian goddess) and she said she would talk to her dead sister that also committed suicide (she also had schizophrenia along with an array of mental illnesses), she claimed she spoke to god and her bipolar moodswings happened every three months. she claimed she got abducted by aliens and they implemented an antenna on her leg which was really just an ingrown hair, and more jarring stories. Schizophrenia can take on a religious manner but it's doesn't always. Also she thought she was here to save the world which is another very common side effect of schizophrenia. I...didn't mean to say this much but I hope my experience can help others either identify to get help or help identify schizophrenia in others. the funny part about everything though was that she was a damn good board certified psychiatrist with the passion and love for her patients. she helped so many people, she was no monster or murderer, she loved movies and going to the theater and eating popcorn, she served this country and suffered RSD (a disorder that causes extreme pain and flare ups in the targeted areas) due to a dead rotting bone in her ankle that could not be removed. I miss you momma, I'll hope your happy and at rest in the heaven you oh so firmly believed in.

My aunt had schizophrenia (she, unfortunately, passed this year of covid-19) and it was very hard seeing what this disease did to her. She was highly paranoid, delusional and depressed... and it was tough seeing her go through all that, seeing her believing things that were not true and seeing her in desperate emotional pain. As someone who saw a VERY loved family member live with schizophrenia and be tagged as "dangerous" and "crazy": I'm beyond thankful that, not only this video exists, but this series exists, and that Anthony is sharing his space and visibility on the internet with people whose stories we all need to hear. The people in this video are incredibly brave and strong and I wish them all only good things in life. And I really hope that one day we can find a cure, or at least better treatments, for this terrible disease.

Great episode!!  I also wanted to add in to Kody Green's last message about people confusing DID for schizophrenia. Recently, I learned that Narcolepsy (a rare sleep disorder that I was diagnosed with 2 years ago) is often misdiagnosed as schizophrenia. Both disorders experience hallucinations and overtime delusions (*for narcolepsy) because you are living in a waking dream. It IS possible to have both conditions, but there ARE distinct differences. People with narcolepsy do not typically respond to the medications prescribed for schizophrenia. If you are unsure if you are schizophrenic or narcoleptic, getting an MLST at a sleep center or from a sleep doctor is the way to check it out. Neurologists or psychiatrists can not usually help in this area. It took me 10+ years to get diagnosed, and before that I thought I was experiencing psychosis and concerned I had a more serious mental condition. So be sure to consider and rule out other brain disorders as well! And if you're curious about the schizophrenia + narcolepsy topic, I had seen a video lecture on YT called "Narcolepsy: a sleep disorder with psychiatric features" by Royal Talks. It talks about the key differences between narcolepsy & schizophrenia and what it looks like when people may have both conditions. Hope all are doing well!! This was a great video. I kinda want to find those schizophrenia simulators now...
I had a psychotic break in highschool and essentially was convinced that everyone on the bus I was on was going to kill me, that they were all there specifically to kill me and I got so terrified I got off the bus and broke down.

I work in a nursing facility with about 212 beds. Approximately 80% of our residents have a diagnosis of schizophrenia or schizoaffective disorder. Honestly, it seems like more of an umbrella-term. Some of our residents, you'd never even expect them to have schizophrenia; others have such debilitating symptoms. Some people have full insight (such as those we see in this video), but many others don't agree with their diagnosis or realize that many of their experiences or beliefs aren't based in reality.  I really like this video because it shows many folks who present as neurotypical. Society typically sees schizophrenics in a certain way, and that's rarely what I see at work each day. Great video.

I get this too, it sucks major frickin balls honestly. My "friends" literally call me psycho at school because of it and the others treat me like I'm not a person anymore. I've been experiencing this since I was like 6ish and nobody believes me. I get told by teachers and my parents that I'm just making it up for attention and that it isn't real, it's all in my head and they don't seem to understand that that is exactly the problem. I have this delusion I guess it would be that I can't have more than one mental disorder, if I have another then obviously I'm faking one of them, right? I know that that isn't how it works, I know it's wrong or bad of me to think like that. But I don't know how to think differently  from that. I get hallucinations of people who don't have faces like Kody (?) does, I can't tell if anything I see is real or not and I haven't found a way that helps me tell. I get so paranoid I can't bring myself to ask someone to help me, to help me get to a doctor or someone that can help me with this. I can't bring myself to go to the doctors cause well if everyone around me is saying I'm faking it, they can't all be wrong can they. If I go to the doctor about it then they'll just turn me away right, tell me I'm faking one of the disorders, I can't have multiple. I want to get around this, does it even count as a delusion if I know that it is wrong? I want to get help but I just CAN'T. It's terrifying, I told my youth group that I suffer from hallucinations and such and they called my parents asking them to make sure that I'm not going to suddenly turn around and stab someone, or throw a glass at someone. I hate it there now, it was my safe place but I don't have one of those anymore. I don't have anyone to go to for help. It's gotten bad enough I've come to a YouTube comment section, fuck what am I doing with my life?
