Thank you Anthony for shedding light on this subject! I live with schizoaffective and it is nice to see individuals who experience the world similar to me. My wishes go out to them and everyone who is affected with this illness üôè
I am a mental health professional and I did my practicum at a residential site for folks with concurrent disorders (both mental health and addictions combined), and I realized almost immediately, thankful to the residents that taught me, that I still had some fears and misconceptions about folks with Schizophrenia. A gentleman explained to me that one day he would be able to walk through walls and leave the site... and it showed me that he truly wanted to be free of that world; I felt so much compassion there, seeing the hard work people do to just function in daily life. Mind you, the folks at this site had severe symptoms, and were struggling to function in the world without constant support, but, I can see how similar these folks are in their depth of bewilderment when discovering they had a mental illness. It just shows you that surrounding circumstances can make all the difference. Some folks turn to substances to cope with their symptoms, some are introduced before the onset of their first break, and some develop addictions later in life after many years of medications not working for them. And the side effects of medications can be so severe, some prefer to live with psychosis rather than deal with what the meds cause for them.
<3 Thanks for the awareness of this misunderstood disorder.  Keep up the amazing work!

I was in a relationship for almost two years, and me and my ex-boyfriend hadn‚Äôt  met in person until we decided to try living together. We were so committed to making everything work with our financial situations. But when I met him in person, I kept noticing that he would often ‚Äútune out‚Äù. He would say to me while we were walking ‚Äúwhy are those girls laughing at me?‚Äù When we hadn‚Äôt passed anyone. He told me there were ghosts that he saw in our apartment. He had times where he was paranoid about the food he ate. And then he had a seizure. It was a focal seizure. He sat and rocked back and forth and whispered things over and over, walked around the apartment. I almost wanted to take him to the emergency room but with covid I knew I couldn‚Äôt. I looked up online the symptoms of schizophrenia and schizoaffective disorder, and saw all of the similarities he had with it. I also saw that people with these disorders are more likely to have epileptic episodes. I was so distraught, but I had to make him move back in with his loving father, who I knew could take care of him better than a college girl could. He had no idea he was suffering so much. I wish I could‚Äôve helped. But after seeing this video I feel firm in my belief that he can recover and hopefully live a more normal life someday. Even if it isn‚Äôt with me.

I have a family member with schizophrenia & I can't express enough how important it is to spread awareness and educate others about it! Thank you for these videos, they're always so well done!
If anyone wants to experience what it could be like for people with this condition they should play the game Hellblade: Senua's Sacrifice¬†and definitely wear headphones!
This is my experience with someone who had schizophrenia. (It's a long read).  My neighbor called me and told me she was babysitting a little girl and she was scared shitless because the little girl was possessed. I laughed, I was 15 at the time and I did not believe in that kind of  thing. She asked me if I could come over and I said yes. When I went over her house, my neighbour was on the varandah with the little girl. The little girl was naked. I said my to Anna (my neighbour), "Why is she naked?" Anna said "she doesn't want to put on her clothes, she's seeing things." So I took the little girl clothes off the ground and I said, "come baby girl, let's put on your blouse." She started screaming, crying, having a fit. The little girl asked me  "if I really didn't see it?" She said her clothes were filled with worms, snakes and roaches. That 'this thing' on the varandah was laughing at her. I attempted to dress her again and her reaction the second time was blood curdling. At this point, Anna ran into the living room. I got goosebumps and I started crying, I hugged her then asked her to show me this thing. She pointed to a corner and I got so angry; I started shouting at the empty corner, telling it, screaming really,  to leave her alone. The little girl said it went away and I was able to put on her underwear. She still would not put on the rest of  her clothes. Anna and I waited  an hour for the little girls' mom to  arrive. During the wait, I tried to get the little girl to play but she was so anxious and uncomfortable. I spoke to the mom. The mom said her daughter started showing the behavior a few months ago. She went to psychologist and they said it was schizophrenia. She was given medication but it barely work. The doctor told her to come back because it can take a while to figure out the right combo of medication. The mother decided to take the spiritual route. She  went to a few pastors who prayed for her but she was still 'sick'. She said she had just came from a spiritualist who said the thing that was attacking her daughter was a friend who had died. The friend was upset that the mom didn't attend the funeral. The little girl's Mom said she indeed had a friend who died and she did not go to the funeral because their relationship was complicated. She said the timeline of the friend's death and the beginning of her daughter's illness did coincide.  The spiritualist told her that she should go to the friend's grave and make peace. The last time I saw that little girl she was fully dressed, waving and smiling at me. Anna told me that the little girl was fine now but that was  14 years ago.

During my psychology degree, it was constantly hypothesised by the lecturers and professors that we haven‚Äôt truly figured out schizophrenia yet and because people experience so many different symptoms, we‚Äôve probably accidentally combined 2 or more mental issues into 1 diagnosis.

I honestly think schizophrenia people can see things that we can't.. like they have access to the other side.  And things do try messing with them. I think they're just super sensitive beings... It really sucks that they can't control it, I don't think they're crazy
I watched a video on a channel called Special Books by Special Kids. They had a man on it named Daniel Nepveux (he has a YT channel all his own now) He deals with Schizoaffective Disorder. he gives a great insight into  how hard it is for some people just to get proper effective treatment for serious mental illness.   I also worked in a mental hospital and just how some of these people are treated by even the nursing staff breaks my heart. I witnessed someone being forced given a needle even though their delusions were telling them the nursing staff and security were trying to kill them (they were restrained to the bed and security holding them down). The whole time, the patient was asking for oral meds instead of the needle because they have had it before (I think there was also a fear of needles too mixed in with the delusion). After the needle was given, the security staff cleared and asked the nurse if there was an oral for the injection. Turned out there was. The reason why I remember this so well is because I was the security staff that asked... I WAS LIVID! Things could have been handled so much differently if the nursing staff wasn't afraid of the patient (injection had a quicker response time) and just listened to them... sure it could have been a delusion but... the injection was exasperating the delusion 10 fold because they were being forced to do something they perceived as scary or ill intent.

I don't have schizophrenia but I have heard sounds and voices while listening to music and sometimes I think I see things in the corner of my eyes.... It's trippy just at that level
TW: Suicide I have anxiety really bad and watching this makes me understand how these people feel. When I had a panic attack I was dissociating really bad; I saw a shadow figure go by the window in the door, and I saw myself hanging from wires tied around my neck. There was several times where I could see myself dying, whether it be from jumping off my bedroom window to ramming a steel rod into my head.  When I was younger people would always call my name then turn around. Now I sometimes hear what sounds like someone said my name when it reality no one said it. Sometimes it happens multiple times before it stops.  Although my anxiety and depression is nothing in comparison to Schizophrenia, I definitely now understand this illness just a little bit more. Can I just say, that Paranoid Schizophrenia, when therapeutically applied to art, creates some of the most detailed, beautiful pieces of art I've ever seen.   If you're interested---as I was---look up 'paranoid schizophrenic draws what they see' and soak up the emotion, and depth of their mind's eye.   The pieces of art I saw were better than some master's work. I'd like to think that these people are blessed and cursed at the same time.   Blessed, because they have vivid imagination and intelligence.  Cursed, because they have to cope and deal with the stress of it for the rest of their lives.

My own experience with psychosis is I‚Äôve never heard or seen someone or something that is not there. I‚Äôve thought the people who were actually around me were saying things that they weren‚Äôt. The things they were telling me weren‚Äôt scary or bad but they were actually encouraging me, telling me I could do it ( I was writing a test) and I felt incredibly useless and confused and depressed. The one visual hallucination I remember is my own face changing when I looked into a mirror. I‚Äôve also hallucinated music before. It‚Äôs different for everyone, and it can be scary but it also depends on how the people around you react towards you.

Just wanted to chime in with a little psych fact! One of the reasons that schizophrenia is sometimes confused with DID is because "schizophrenia" literally means "splitting of the mind." [Greek roots: *schizo* (split) + *phren* (mind).] The name is meant to describe a "loosened" mental state, but some people take it literally and just think, "Oh, split personalities." Hope that helps clear things up :)

My dad's aunt had schizophrenia since she was 16. Soon she became addicted to her meds and smoking.  Whenever we visited her she was kind and loving, but I remeber how she would answer our questions with totally different things. My dad said she imagined what the conversation would go like and then even if it didn't go that way she would still think it did. Sadly I only learned about her disorder after her death, but I wish my parents would have told me sooner. When a couple of years ago I started hearing a voice who would whisper in my ear and I would feel like someone was following me all day I think my dad was scared I would end up like his aunt. Now I don't hear that voice anymore and I was diagnosed with deppression and anxiety this year but that year when I experienced those things was frightening ( I was 14 ). I think we should be teaching kids to talk about their feelings and thoughts, good and bad! because we all have an instinct to what is healthy feelings and what might be harmful feelings/thoughts. And parents/adults need to learn how to shut up and listen! But mental health in more depth, like different diagnoses, maybe wait til they're passed puberty. No matter what a child is feeling/expressing, there should be no shame and no words like "don't cry, don't be scared, stop screaming" because that will teache the child that it's not ok to express the whole spectrum of feelings and they start turing it inwards. Help them process those feelings and put the right word there, if they're crying, confirm them: "you look sad, do you want a hug" if they're angry and throwing a fit "you seem really really mad, do you want to be alone or do you want to breath a bit"... it gives them SO MUCH understanding of themselves and of others an they become empathetic at a very early age. And it gives them tools to express themselves in words instead of throwing things or harming themselves or others.

Thank you so much for doing this, also for finding all these wonderful people, who would like to share. This disorder is one of the huge things that effect my everyday life, as my little brother has a combination of all the symptoms of the different types. I love him, but it is hard. He is seen as someone who is weird or scary, and it breaks my heart, because I know how much he want to be accepted. (By anyone really..) I know it can be hard when you see someone who talks to himself/or what he see, is forced to hear loud music outside, or on the train. Strangers stare at him, whisper when they see him, and it makes it worse. It triggers manic episodes, and it make me wish people had more knowledge about mental health and mental disorders in generel. It's not fun, if you start laughing with some friends, and point at someone because they behave different. This happens often.. And what these people dont know, is that the rude behavior they show, gives him suicidal thoughts.   At first I honestly didnt know much about schizophrenia before my brother was diagnozed, and I was shocked how much I thought I know that was just bullshit. But one thing I also wish people know, (some dont like to hear it) but in my brothers case it is likely that starting to do weed made the symptoms worse. Before that, he had a few symptoms but we could handle it. After, it got really bad. I dont care about your opinion about weed or drugs, but if you are someone who read this and are thinking it would help to calm you down - Even if I am a stranger, I hope you will try getting help in another way. There are no turning back for my brother, I can only be there for him, support him, love him, but smoking a lot of weed did make his symptoms a lot worse. So please dont take it lightly.

Distraction is exactly what I use to cope with my schizophrenia. My story has been a bit rocky and I‚Äôm still taking it day by day but I definitely feel like I‚Äôm in a place where I‚Äôm stable-ish. 20 years of this has been taxing but I generally feel like it is such a norm for me that I don‚Äôt mention that I have it to people because I‚Äôm not constantly thinking ‚ÄúI have schizophrenia ‚Äú. The thought doesn‚Äôt cross my mind to say anything because it‚Äôs like... telling someone your shoe size. Why would they need to know your shoe size to be your friend? A lot of people I know don‚Äôt know or think that I have schizophrenia. It‚Äôs not noticeable. I‚Äôve had this for so long that it‚Äôs impossible for me to lose it when I hallucinate in front of other people. The only person who can tell that I‚Äôm actively hallucinating sometimes is my mom. I‚Äôll glance at the ceiling or outside of a window and really lock eyes with what I‚Äôm seeing and immediately look away just like someone would do if they saw a car go by outside they would look out of the window for a second and see it go by and then go back to what they were doing but in my case what was on the ceiling or outside of the window is still there I just decided that by trying to.... god it‚Äôs hard to explain... it‚Äôs like mentally changing a conversation and by doing that I can go on with what I was doing.

From age 5 to 8 I have had something like the schizophrenia that Cecilia described herself having, I would see things like sometimes I would see spiders crawling all around the room, sometimes I would look out the window a see a man with a huge smile on his face and bloodshot red eyes, and I would most often see a blue ball that could talk and it had human skin. And if I ever looked in a top corner I would see a man looking with his head twisted around. One time I walked into my living room and fell to the floor and everything looked as if it was shaking, my mom walked in the room and asked me what I was doing and I was so confused why she didn‚Äôt feel it. I would have terrible nightmares every night, one specifically I remember I heard a loud noise so I walked out to see what was happening and I saw my parents getting ripped apart by some type of monster. I would have to have my parents called sometimes in class because when I was scared and I would yell and scare other kids. At first my parents wrote it off as my imagination since I was so young but eventually they decided to check in with people. They never figured out what was wrong but I know it wasn‚Äôt schizophrenia because that doesn‚Äôt go away. I will say one thing though, it helped me get over any fears I might have had in the future like spiders and stuff, I like spiders now.

You should do an episode on Ehler Danlos Syndrome (EDS). It‚Äôs a connective tissue disorder that mainly causes joint pain and dislocations, but it commonly affects all sorts of bodily systems. It can sometimes cause life threatening complications. It can be very hard to get diagnosed because many people ignore our pain or don‚Äôt believe it exists. Even though it‚Äôs considered a disability, many people with other disabilities tell us we‚Äôre making everything up and we don‚Äôt belong. It would be awesome to bring more awareness and to get people to understand that an ‚Äúinvisible‚Äù disability can cause just as much hardship as any other.

I don't have schizophrenia but I have experienced hallucinations and delusions in my childhood. I can say for sure that until you get a moment of clarity you have no way of discerning if it's real or not. I've see how people look at you like you're broken if you let them know what you're experiencing. I've had people in the hospital I was staying at not know what to do with me because that specific unit wasn't trained for it. All of that being said, get the help you need. Go to people that are trained in your type of symptoms and they will help you. You will find the right medication or treatment and you will get better. I appreciate the optimism in this episode. I grew up seeing some of the extremes of schizophrenia through my uncle. He never did anything that was scary; rather, he really struggled with his basic self-care and with socializing. Music was the only time he behaved like "his old self" as described by my grandparents. It wasn't until college that I met someone who lived with what I considered well-managed schizophrenia, Professor Elyn Saks.  It is so important to see more examples of people living with schizophrenia who don't fit the stereotypes. I'm so grateful to the folks that came on this show and put a very relatable face to what is so often a falsely villainized disorder.

I‚Äôve been having Hallucinations and delusions since 2017. I‚Äôve had professionals tell me that I‚Äôm just experiencing psychosis, even after I found out that schizophrenia runs in the family.  I‚Äôve been told that the ‚Äúvoices‚Äù are just thoughts, but I hear it externally and some of the things said I would never think about. The things I see terrify me. Sometimes I can tell they are fake but most of the time they seem to be the most real thing. I ran away for three days once without bothering to put on a pair of shoes because I swore someone was after me. I just wanted to disappear so they couldn‚Äôt find me. Everyday is a struggle and since I lost my health insurance and don‚Äôt have access to the meds that helped take the edge off. And I‚Äôm left frustrated because I don‚Äôt believe that I simply am experiencing psychosis because of my Major Depressive Disorder. And that has been especially stressful lately. But this video gives me hope that I‚Äôll figure out what exactly is wrong with me. Gives me the confidence that I can lead some kind of normalcy. Because these last few days I haven‚Äôt been sure if it‚Äôs worth even fighting for my needs. This video just helped me realize that‚Äôs exactly what I need to do. This is probably going to be a highly unpopular opinion but I've been on a "spiritual" journey for years and have always gone through life "different" and even took myself to see drs. Psychologists,therapists,councilors, etc explaining why I believed there was something "wrong" with me (via these "textbook explanations of certain illness's") and my mind since it didn't fit in with the current blueprint of society. I was told over and over that there was nothing wrong with me and that my awareness to everything was why I was 100% completely sane, yet I would feel like I was in a lucid dream etc etc.. but I have to say that has been the greatest thing to ever happen to me,( having drs not believe me or feel I was completely sane and having to figure that shiz out all on my own) because I believe we as a society try to suppress things to fit into neat little boxes and suppress things we don't have full understanding of. And he mentioned another youtuber obsessed with the number 9, again; not alone in this. November is CRPS Awareness Month. Would be great to see a video bring information to more people.   It's a horrific nerve disorder that causes the highest medically-rated physical pain. Think of the moment of the worst pain you've ever had -- perhaps the moment you broke a leg, for example. Normally, the wound heals and the pain lessens. Not with CRPS. The wound heals and every single moment of every single day for the rest of your life, you will always feel that highest level of pain forever....there is never a pause to catch a breath or even think straight. CRPS was first discovered over 150 years ago and still has no cure. Sometimes it's brought on by an injury and sometimes it just spontaneously begins. It can affect anywhere on the body, including internal organs. There's no rhyme or reason to who, what, where, or when and no one has figured out why yet.  All it takes is the right person out there learning about it to start the journey towards finding effective treatments.   The human body is not built to withstand this much pain continously. Convincing ourselves to make it to the next moment because there's always a reason to cling to hope. However, so many of us try very hard to make every moment of life matter to everyone we meet. We carve out meaningful lives in spite of the horrific pain we face. We eventually learn how to keep a straight face most of the time....how to appear smiling and "normal" as best we can. We're still human even as our nervous system and pain receptors betray us. Sometimes it's hard to remember what life was like "before".  We really need the visibility because there are so many medical professionals that have been in the Healthcare field for decades and never encountered a patient with CRPS or even heard of it. Not long ago, there were few people that had heard of breast cancer or ALS or any number of now highly visible disorders. It took hard work spreading education and awareness to bring those to light. We're hoping CRPS awareness becomes visible as well. üéó

Never in my life I experienced anything similar again

As a child of a parent with bipolar, hearing these experiences are so helpful. It seems like the dialogue surrounding mental health often tries to dilute mental illness, like depression being "just sad" or anxiety being "quirky". Talking about mania, and the hallucinations, and the downright out of body experiences really shed light on these "taboo" subjects. Medication can help tremendously, and these diagnoses are only the first step to becoming the best version of yourself! In America, the mental health system is often a joke, but please know there are people to help advocate for you and get the care that you need! We all need help at different points in our life and there is no shame in asking and seeking treatment. What i'm getting at is, thank you all for sharing your experiences! This series is wonderful.

I'm schizophrenic and am so thankful to be stable after a few psych wards and years of medication trial and error. My husband has good insurance which has covered my psych stays and medications. So many people do not have access to the care that allows me to live a relatively normal life.

etikas story is so heartbreaking man. I feel for jorge dude i still think about etika and miss him so much. I really wish a  bunch of people didnt clown on him and drive him to the point he got to.
My grandma had Paranoid Schizophrenia. She'd whisper to herself. I didn't think it was strange because she had been like that my whole life. It wasn't until I was seven that my mom told me that grandma was... different. My mom had been telling me since I could talk not to talk to myself. I realized it was because she was afraid I was like grandma. It wasn't until I was a teenager that I realized how bad the delusions were for grandma. She explained to me that her neighbor didn't like her carpet and he forced her to replace it. Catholic nuns weren't to be trusted because they worked for the devil. Doctors moved around her bones and made her body look different. These were kind of scary to hear. my mom explained that grandma stopped taking her meds before I was born because she didn't want to fall asleep while babysitting my older cousins.  Grandma had moments of clarity. I remember once, when she was in the hospital on a respirator, my mom told us not to get emotional and upset grandma. we walk in and immediately mom begins to cry and grandma opens her arms for a hug and rocks my mom side to side. usually her delusions rule her life and keep her from interacting with her children. so this was pretty incredible (as she aged the delusions got so bad she was constantly whispering to herself and not acknowledging people when they were talking to her). she was an incredible person. a nurse for 30 years and a loving mother and grandmother. while she didn't go about life "normally" she was still very loving to her family. incredibly non-violet despite what Hollywood would have us believe. she'd only get mad at one of us if we challenged her delusions. so we stopped doing that because all it accomplished was stressing her out and making ourselves frustrated.  end of novel.

I sincerely hope this doesnt come off as tone deaf, but for years, I wished for the diagnoses of schizophrenia. Ive experienced frequent hallucinations, hundreds per day, always startling, always adrenaline pumping, and often I'll have to ask my partner if they saw what I saw. I've spoken to therapists and seen neurologists, and no one has a solid answer, Brain scans dont side towards schizophrenia nor epilepsy, and I wish I was able to find an answer. The cloesest ive come to is discussing my situation with others who have Aspergers/Autism (as I do aswell), and realising that a lot of people on the spectrum experience very similar hallucinations. This video really highlighted the experience of the people I originally thought I would be apart of, and how my experience is indeed different from schizophrenia. These videos help to not only clarify and discuss the main topics in question, but clarifying other topics that may be confused with them. Being able to see the real life experiences of people with this disorder helped clarify my own situation, and for that Im truly grateful. Thank you as always for making this content Anthony (and his hard working crew!)

I am not schizophrenic but do experience visual hallucinations when I get stressed or anxious. I mean MAYBE I do but my therapist and psychiatrist say it‚Äôs because of my extreme anxiety disorders. I would hallucinate the girl from the ring and she would stand in corners or crawl by me and I was delusional thinking she was going to kill me or hurt my pets. I also saw this really big tall guy in all red clothing just growing in size at the end of my bed. I have also seen people‚Äôs faces distort and see animals where they shouldn‚Äôt be and then I usually just see textures moving like rough carpet looking like static or computer screens scribing like water. When these things occur I know I need to take some time to de stress and calm down and just exist and be around people. I had other delusions but idk how to describe them as they were so extremely weird and out there. But yeah I keep in touch with my parents and friend and therapist to make sure these things don‚Äôt start up really bad again, I just got to exist and not stress so much ya know? If I have schizophrenia I have it and I can‚Äôt change it so I refuse to worry over it because it‚Äôll just make it worse in the end

my family had a discussion the other day talking about schizophrenia. My sisters were talking about how our mother was very violent and had very bad anger problems and took it out on all the people around her. Talking about how she was being schizo and psycho while she was pregnant with another daughter in the discussion and that's why that particular daughter is so violent too. Being the only one near the conversation with any understanding of the condition at all. I had to tell them that that was not how schizophrenia works. So the stigma about schizophrenics being violent still goes strong and it kind of annoys me. I know alot about the condition because I have been afflicted with this mental illness almost my entire life. I have made it to a point where I understand all the things I did and why, But before I knew I had these conditions I was a very miserable girl I felt like I couldn't understand myself because my tastes and interests changed and changed back so frequently I couldn't keep up. The thoughts in my head were so prevalent that I thought it was normal to think with voices that spoke with different personalities. Or to hear feel and see things that werent there. I felt like I was in a deep dark pit within myself surrounded by darkness and nobody else could or would help me out. Luckily I had some special abilities and they lead me to New Age movement. I predicted some birth days and also both my grandparents Death days. I asked for the dates and they were given to me and I waited. On the marked days the predictions came true. This is when I realised that the world was much bigger than the physical and I went on to get spiritual help and I found it in Dolores Cannons work. With her technique I found that the whole universe lives within the mind as much as it is outside, and if I learned to harness the ability to communicate between the physical and spiritual then maybe I can lift myself out from the pits. Now I have found out how to protect myself from the more scary hallucinations, I dont feel as paranoid all the time. Now that I have found out how to manage my personalities better I dont feel so confused about who I am. I am the observer and I give my energy where I feel is most beneficial to my growth as a being of light and love.

The girl reminded me what kind of happens to me. I have serious arachnophobia and when I see them, like I did on this video. I start to see them or think of them as if they are in my reality. I wake up from nightmares and would throw off my blanket, shake it, and turn on a light until I calmed down. I would be afraid that my dog was actually a spider and I was hallucinating it was a dog.

I found cody on TikTok and binged all his videos. Keep up the great work Anthony
I've been afraid of one day developing schizophrenia because of how terrifying it seems like it would be to live with, especially if I were to develop it now as a college student after going my whole life without it. Especially if I were to hallucinate terrifying figures like the blob or the clown that Cecilia mentioned. I've experienced auditory hallucinations before, but I know those can happen to people without schizophrenia as well. Sometimes when I'm struggling to fall asleep and it's just too quiet, I think I hear a radio playing softly. It almost sounds like it's one room over, but as soon as I sit up and try to actively pay attention to it, I can't hear it anymore. I have a hard time shutting my brain off at night, so it's probably related to that. My roommate experiences auditory hallucinations when her anxiety gets really bad too. But the extent to which people with Schizophrenia experience hallucinations is something I can't begin to imagine. My closest understanding of it is how it's portrayed in A Beautiful Mind.
This video is very much appreciated and very personal to me. As someone who's mom had Schizophrenia (among other disorders) we need more attention on these things. My mom unfortunately did not get the correct help she needed and ended up having a major episode that resulted in me being taken away from her. It didn't help that we weren't in our home country (Ireland) and the US was and so is very bad at dealing with the situations. If we better understood these issues, I think today I would still be with my mother, but we are now a whole ocean away and that does weigh on me. Overall though, I worry about my own mental Health since I already have Anxiety and Panic Disorder, yet I feel like videos like these help to better the situation of people like my mom and others. Luckily she has been able to transition properly and today she is mostly unaffected by her disorder which is great, but at her peak it was terrible and I don't wish it on anyone else. Let's fight to fix this

Thank you so much for this Anthony and all of the people who spoke on this. My sister struggles so much with her schizophrenia. She started showing symptoms while she was 15 and I was 9. It was hard seeing her go through something I could not experience myself. She was diagnosed at 16 and has struggled every day with it. She is 27 now and she just now found the right dose and medication after years of trying. If anyone with schizophrenia or someone who knows someone with schizophrenia please know it is manageable. You can live your life to the fullest extent and you will find people who will accept you for all of you. Anyone who loves someone with schizophrenia: please allow the person to talk about what they're going through if they need to. Don't act scared or creeped out. Comfort them if they're overwhelmed. If you notice them disassociating ask if there is a place they would be more comfortable. It's trial and error. Just be as understanding as you can be :)

Right so... I don't think I have schizophrenia, as far as I know (but who even knows at this point I have so many other problems). But I have had both auditory and visual hallucinations due to extreme stress apparently(???) is what I've been told (by my mother and doctors at the (psychward). I remember seeing floating heads round me and various monsters, and like... it was so fucking scary, I had never seen anything like this before and as a fairly logical individual I thought "why am I seeing this? These things should exist why are they here why am I seeing this, is this real, are they going to hurt me?" etc. etc. At that time I was all alone in my room only on a call with two people online and no one could be there to reassure me.  The auditory hallucinations weren't scary at all though, from what I can remember. I apparent heard lots of knocking in the walls when I was in the ward and I didn't know they weren't real. I apparently told the people working there that I couldn't sleep because someone was knock and it was annoying or something(?) and they never heard anything. It was probably recreating the reason I was in the ward at the first place.  I can maybe think that after several years of this that maybe one could get used to it a bit. I think after a while maybe the floating heads wouldn't leave me in a shaking screaming mess on the floor but who knows. However IDK if I'd be able to get used to knock in the walls at 1AM when I try to sleep. xD

My sister was diagnosed as schizophrenic and suffers a lot with psychosis after a bad nervous breakdown a few years ago, and I can't even imagine her being dangerous to anyone but herself. She's so full of constant anxiety and spends all her time trying to organise what she's doing and keeping herself busy so she isn't distracted by what she calls "the lecturers" that she says talk to her through family members and the radio. It can be stressful for family too, being that she's always so overly anxious and paranoid, but it's not her fault. Please never get annoyed or frustrated with someone over anxiety, they may be dealing with something more than just worry, and just because you may think they're overreacting, the worst situations are very possible to them.

I sincerely thank you, Anthony, for bringing attention to those of us with mental illnesses. People need to realize that mental illnesses are  like having high blood pressure or diabetes. They are an illness in the brain, often much worse than a general illness.   My husband has had a mental diagnosis that increased in intensity about 2 years ago and it continues to affect him. They are still trying to get the ideal med combinations to help him. There‚Äôs sometimes weeks that he just can‚Äôt leave the house to go to work. Just since last Friday he‚Äôs missed 3 days.   I was diagnosed in 2006. It also took years of going through so many meds, until they finally had me stabilized. But the brain changes and they have to adjust again. Three times different meds completely affected me in a really bad way. I have no doubt they caused some brain damage.   Everyone has a story. The above are just 2 examples. a couple of years ago i went into an amphetamine induced psychosis (i used to be extremely self destructive & am now doing a bit better & getting the help that i need). i had very vivid auditory & visual hallucinations & it was one of the scariest moments of my life. not being in control of what u perceive as real/imaginary is terrifying. since then i became quite paranoid & ive realized schizophrenia actually runs in my family which kinda explained why this affected me so much. even tho i don't experience this on a daily basis, i'm so thankful that ur doing this and providing a safe space for all to share & start a conversation about their own experience.  love u all, dont do drugs (especially if ur mentally ill) ! ‚ù§Ô∏è

I actually have been experiencing what these guys are describing, just the opposite. I have very vivid dreams, and I've been able to feel, taste, hear, and touch things in dreams, so the line between reality and dreaming has become more blurred for me. I also have memories of these vivid dreams and I can see details in them. Does anyone know what this might be?
Hope he someday do a "i spent a day with people with adhd/add"
I am not diagnosed with shizophrenia, but i show a lot of signs and think that i may just be in an early state.   I have always had depression and severe social anxiety, and I startet visually hallucinating 3 years ago. It mostly happened during school, i would zone out, see shadow people walk around me, and not be able to put my consciousness back into my body. I often also couldn't do my work as i was hallucinating too much and couldn't see my paper, or as i would see my table shake violently.  I had a lot of neurological checks as i also had very bad migraines back then, and was submitted to a therapist 2 years ago.  Last year my DP/DR started. I would physically feel absolutely nothing, and life would feel like a dream. My own movements & voice were unbelievable and distant to me, i felt like a robot which was controlled by someone else. When i wasn't able to find anything online about it, i came to the conclusion that i must simply be dead. It was horrifying. This state held on for about a month, and i only remember pieces of about 2 days, the rest is simply gone, as if i had a blackout.  I now also sometimes have auditory hallucinations, and i feel things that aren't there. I also have delusions, thinking that i can affect the world around me: for example i search for something, while thinking "i am not gonna find it", and it ends up not being there, even though it should be.  At the moment i am having trouble with sleeping. I easily sleep for 16 hours even though i do not want to sleep this much. I sleep so much because my dreams feel like an eternity. I feel like i am living for weeks and weeks in my dreams, i also wake up several times while still dreaming and think that i am awake, when in reality i'm not. I don't know how to stop these vivid dreams. I cannot part my dreams from reality anymore, i sometimes am convinced that something that happened in my dream has happened in real life. I also sometimes confuse my real life with my dreams, thinking stuff like "if i fuck up i can just restart, because this is a dream/a videogame" though i don't even play videogames.  There's a lot of things that are also pointing towards shizophrenia, but i cannot list them all, especially as i mostly forget a lot lately. I've started forgetting simple things like faces, names, or events in my life, though i have always had a very great memory, and it's very scary to me, as i feel like i'm slowly slipping away.
My mother has schizophrenia... she's one of the softest sweetest people I know.

I had no idea what anxiety can do to a body until it happened to me, and it‚Äôs devastating. Having doctors tell me all tests come back clear but you‚Äôre still in physical pain or throwing up and not able to eat and doctors just say ‚Äúoh it‚Äôs your mental health, get that fixed then your body will be fixed‚Äù. I‚Äôd love to see people have more understanding of anxiety and the difference between natural nerves and an anxiety disorder and what and why things can cause it. I‚Äôm so proud of each and everyone of theses guests for talking about the disorder they live and cope with. There is so much courage in it. These guys are the role models we need.

As a schizophrenic myself it was nice to see this. When I told my class I had schizophrenia during the mental health class one of my classmates actually called campus police on me and then I got investigated which just absolutely destroyed me. Everyone looked at me as a normal person but they all changed when I said what I had. I personally hear a voice very rarely saying my name in my ear or I‚Äôll hear a flood of voices like I‚Äôm in a crowded room. Let me tell you, not flinching while talking to a teacher and you hear your name being shouted in rage right in your ear is hard. I see shadow people or just a normal person but they usually disappear as soon as I see them. For the ones that don‚Äôt, if I‚Äôm at home, I just curl up, close my eyes, and hug myself because seeing it sends intense panic through me even if it‚Äôs not scary. I tell people what i have and if they really care for me as a friend they‚Äôll stay. I do D&D with my friends and one mentioned how my new character was like a schizophrenic since they have a spirt friend that no one else can see when they stopped when they realized what they said and tried to apologize to me. Now, THIS IS NOT THE SAME FOR EVERYONE, but I completely do not mind jokes and I even make them myself with my knowing friends. I told them it was all good and the group of us when back and forward making jokes regarding the topic. I personally like this because it shows me that people aren‚Äôt afraid or restricted for what they can say to me. We‚Äôre not psychos and killers like the tv makes us out to be, just people living as normal lives as they can day by day. Don‚Äôt be afraid and instead try to understand what kind of a package deal we are. That‚Äôs it for my rant. Stay safe and I love you all ‚ù§Ô∏è

Classmates saying she'd hear voices in her head, she might try hurt me or herself infront of me and I wanted to give it a try because I did like her. Out of the many girls she didn't wear too much make up, she looked pretty average, not to say she wasn't pretty, she was but not like the other girls. So I was interested to learn about her, see what she's really like.  After months of dating though, things were awkward and when I tried to ask about what exactly she saw or heard she changed subjects, not wanting to discuss it. In retrospect I pushed alittle too hard maybe? Being too curious and not focusing on her instead. Parents got her a little apartment and she lives there, working now on her own and living well apparently. This is crazy, I am pretty sure i have this and felt so identified with the things they talked about. When I was  eight I reocurringly saw my minds interpretation of the boogieman. He was like a fusion between the rook and the knight chess pieces, but blurry and it had no legs, instead he walked forward moving back and forth like those chairs that lean forward and back. Nowadays when I am in intense tests my vision becomes blurred and when I set an alarm I check like seven times to see if i REALLY put it. And when I close my eyes to sleep I sometimes hear voices, but not creepy ones, I just hear my mom talking about the shopping list right next to me, but in reality its 5am and alone in my room. I even considered I had DID. It doesn't really affect me that much,  I don't have visual hallucinations anymore and only sometimes hear voices and have blurry vision, so its probably slight schizophrenia.
I will say that when schizophrenics are in the wild, we are more likely to kill and harm each other.
My grandmother and my mother struggle with schizophrenia. They both deny that they have it when they are professionally diagnosed. My grandmother needs to be looked after. My mother is homeless in Washington. She went to move in with my uncle, he ended up kicking her out, because she lost her job again. I live in Michigan with my father. My mother has horrible episodes and quits jobs or never goes to her job. My mother denied that she will be getting evicted and told me that we have somewhere to stay. when we did not. I worry about my mom a lot. I never want her to be in any kind of danger.

My ex-girlfriend has schizophrenia. After she broke up with me she wanted to stay friends and at first I tried to. But then I couldn't handle it anymore, because I was still in love. A few months later I wanted to reconnect, because I knew I was over her. She had always said she didn't want to lose me as a friend. But after two attempts of mine to reconnect (where I also stated that she could tell me if she didn't want contact) she blocked me without telling me why. I am fairly certain that was her paranoia and not her pushing me away.  She was really pessimistic about her condition and sad because she couldn't finish her studies because of it and be independent. I tried to cheer her up and make her believe that things could get better, but that only made her more suspicious of my intentions (she suspected I wanted her to go off her meds for example, which I obviously didn't want her to do). I still worry about her every time I think of her. I was her only friend when she still lived in my city. Now she lives back with her family, who she also has to support financially. I hope they can keep her save.

When is he going to talk about Mickey
Treated twice, never diagnosed, and all meds ended up being bad. Several years ago, I OD'd on Abilify and Geodone because I just wasn't feeling good, being unable to sleep for 3 days when I started Abilify... ... What I saw with some people's lives with meds (some, not all)... was they seemed to be more dehabilitated on their meds than off. I've been off meds for years, and I was terrified I was going to go back on meds with my hospitalization back in January 2020.  I've seen people conducting themselves well and much better on meds, but I've also seen some people do worse and unable to do better ever again since they started meds.  With the 'Thorazine Shuffle' ...people stuck drooling, overeating, and unable to drive a car... the effing lawsuit against Risperdal, and Seroquel making my uvula flap in my throat swell up, I'm convinced medication should not be 'deified' in the world of medicine in the same vein as flu shots and antibiotics. In fact, psychiatric drugs should probably be a last resort. Drugs seem to make doctors look lazy, and I feel like there needs to be more advanced therapy to help people regain the willpower and awareness necessary to take back control of their lives.  Psychiatric medication is horrendously over-respected and should not be deemed just as safe as the meds which keep our bodies healthy.  Mind health is absolutely not the same as health of the body, and should not be effing lumped together in world of pharmaceutical medicine. F-that.

I would love to see a day spent with maladaptive daydreamers! It's a condition where you daydream excessively and it affects your life. You end up spending hours in your imagination than living reality. Spending 10 hours in your head instead of doing work, leaving the house, talking to friends, etc. Its been recently discovered and talk about. It's not in DSM yet due to little research.

Some years ago I read a book about someone who had overcome schizophrenia. It was a really interesting and amazing story, but also very hard as the author herself is the one who dealt with it. It's called I morgen var jeg alltid en l√∏ve, litteral translation, Tomorrow I was always a lion. Her struggle through the years to get through it all and how she describes it is just so thought inducing. There is an english translation for anyone who's interested. A road back from schizophrenia, a memoir, by Arnhild Lauveng. The author tells the story about her own road from schizophrenia, how she struggled with it for ten years, and how she overcame it. She is now off medication, and a psycologist. I really recommend it to anyone who wants to learn more. Keep in mind, as we all should for many illnesses we don't really know about, that this is how -she- experienced it. This illness is not the same for everyone. But it's still such a great look into what it could be, and the struggles that was faced during all this.

14:10 ya people who say to just touch them and you‚Äôll know don‚Äôt understand. Because some of us who have disorders that cause hallucinations can have tactile hallucinations too, meaning sometimes you could FEEL something that isn‚Äôt there as well. When I‚Äôve been manic I‚Äôve had hallucinations of all 5 senses, and delusions that have made me completely change my daily routine for a few weeks because I feared for my life before returning to reality and going back to my normal routines. My brother has schizophrenia. Honestly, I respect and applaud these people who are able to battle this disease successfully, but I must say in my experience with my brother it is extremely toxic. He falls right into the category of extreme violence, and since getting schizophrenia, he has lost his ability to speak, he only mumbles words, and communication of any form is very hard for him. He's been in and out of the hospitals for over 20 years due to his violent mental breakdowns. Because of this, I've spent every day of my life growing up scared that one day I would start presenting symptoms like him, especially since the disease didn't start until his late 20s. And yeah, not sure where I'm going with this, but I'm glad to see that some people are able to function rather normally with schizophrenia.

I would love to see an episode on fibromyalgia/chronic fatigue syndrome. I just recently in the last couple years or so got my fibro diagnosis, and it makes such a huge difference knowing that there's a medical cause for why I can't do all the things I'm socially expected to, and having an explanation for all my symptoms. Also because I know from experience that lots of people with fibro don't realise that their experiences are different from normal people. I always thought that I was just lazy or weak because when you're young you don't realise that not everybody lives the same world you do, so I assumed I was just whining about the same kind of pain everyone just dealt with. Nobody talked about it, so I must have been making a big deal out of normal shit - but actually, nobody talked about it because it's not typical, and it's really important to have the information out there that actually, these things are symptoms and not just normal everyday stuff for everyone.

Outing myself here but this needs to be said: When people with schizophrenia such as myself tell other people about their condition- please guys. Please stop looking at us as if we are broken. Im diagnosed with Catatonic and Paranoid schizophrenia. My worst incident is I shaved part of head and cut into my scalp looking for a microchip because I was convinced I was chipped by the government. It's some scary shit.
I am so glad to see you this topic being covered and a conversation being had about schizophrenia on such a large platform and it is my hope that this conversation  will continue because this has been a disease diagnosis that has been so broadly misunderstood and stigmatized (largely from the entertainment industry and how it has painted this diagnosis) that I really hope change in our community and Society takes place. Change is long overdue in how we treat people with psychiatric diagnosis especially that of schizophrenia or psychosis.  I personally had and have people in my life with this diagnosis and I had said and done some very cruel unkind and ignorant actions that were so hurtful in the past that I wish so badly I could take back due to my lack of understanding and ignorance . It wasn't until I went through an episode of temporary psychosis due to rapid changes to seizure medications I was prescribed  that I then really understood how debilitating and helpless and individual can be when experiencing hallucinations,  paranoia and delusions. I for about a three-week period  of time during that medication shift experienced auditory hallucinations, debilitating paranoia and delusions and had no ability to differentiate reality from fiction. It truly was one of the most frightening difficult experiences  in my life and I cannot imagine having to live that everyday. After going through that experience and then reflecting on my previous actions to those in my life with this diagnosis felt horrifically ashamed and realized how ignorant I had been.  Ever since then I  have felt so strongly that as a society we really need to embrace psychiatric diagnosis with compassion, love and  understanding and need much more education to break down the stigmas surrounding it.  Aside from having such helpful videos like this one and conversations that raise awareness we as a society need to send a message to Hollywood and the entertainment industry that we will not support movies, TV shows or any forms of entertainment that spread misinformation around schizophrenia that paint this diagnosis and others like it as people who are violent or cause harm because it creates a culture of fear and that culture needs to end because it is so inaccuratee.   Thank you to each and every individual that spoke openly about having this diagnosis to help spread awareness as I can only imagine how frightening it can be to discuss something that makes someone so vulnerable. Mental Health is just as real and valid as physical health and for whatever reason it seems to be socially acceptable to treat them differently then someone who strictly has a medical condition when truly there is no difference in biological origin of either. Whether you're symptoms be something as pain from a broken limb or hallucinations from a mental illness both are real neither are the individuals fault and both come from a true biological and physiological origin so why they get treated differently doesn't make sense.  Thank you again to all involved in bringing up this discussion and much love to anyone dealing with mental health issues or psychiatric diagnosis. Please know that you are not alone, it is not your fault and you are not the problem. The problem is misinformation and a society that needs to grow in its education and compassion.
My mother has schizophrenia and she is the sweetest women alive. She would walk an hour and a half if i was sick just to get me some ginger tea. I wish her mother would have accepted her because her mother was loving towards her then she got diagnosed and she basically disowned her emotionally. Right now my mother is living in BC, Canada and im two provinces away, it is a struggle to try to get her proper care during Covid, she wasnt able to get her medication and she had an episode which the cops came and she felt threatened and smashed a glass over a cops head. Shes now in court, but I want to see specifically trained nurses that will take in my mother not the same people that take in criminals and have guns which luckily in her case they did not use.

I‚Äôm scared because I‚Äôm either a very light schizophrenic or just a moron

For anyone dealing with this awful disease, I want to share a happy story with you all.. I had schizophrenia for 17 years. I had my first symptoms when I was 11 years old. I started hearing voices. I was struggling with alot of things, and soon after that I started seeing things. I was depressed, bullied, got an eating disorder. I started feeling things. Someone touching me.. I remember how I would be sitting infront of my computer and I would feel someone grabbing my arm. I would turn around and usually I would see this family - Mum, dad and a kid. All dead.. It was so scary!! In my teenage years I got in and out of the psychiatric ward. I saw all kind of things, shadows following me, birds, people that weren‚Äôt there. I started smelling this very specific scent. I could also taste it. I had voices in my head constantly. I thought people could hear what I was thinking. I was sure that there was camera‚Äôs in my entire home, spying on me. When I was outside I was sure someone was following me. I struggled with really bad anxiety, self harm, depression, anorexia, ocd behavior. I tried to take my own life. It was bad.  When I was 17 I had to live at this place for mentally ill people. I stayed there for 8 months and left even more sick. Straight back to the psychiatric ward. 4 months later I was moved to a new place. My parents were told that I was extremely sick, and so sick I would have to live at a place like that for my entire life. I wouldn‚Äôt ever be able to live a normal life.  At 20 I moved into my first apartment. I was still very sick, but I was a little better. I started having talks with a woman at the psychiatry and started new medication. This worked very well! All my psychotic things stopped! And I started working super hard with all my issues (also the things next to my schizophrenia of course)   I am 28 today. About 4 months ago I was told that I no longer have schizophrenia. I NEVER thought this would happen!! I believe they say there‚Äôs a 25% chance for recovery. And I am one of them..   For about 6 years I was on a very very low dose of my medication. A little over a year ago I completely stopped taking it - I haven‚Äôt had any symptoms.   This is a disease that kills people. This is a disease that is SO missunderstood. You hear about it in movies and series - Killers, psychos.. We are not. But we are being tormented by our own head, and it is awful. It is so so hard.   I wish for everyone with this illness all the best. I know it might look hopeless, like it won‚Äôt ever get better. Trust me, I have been there. Now I am here and so happy that my suicide attempt failed. It will get better ‚ù§Ô∏è You‚Äôve got this. Find the right medication, find someone professional to talk to. Get help, work with yourself as hard as you can. You can do this!!
I find it funny how people in movies with schizophrenia or DID are often portrayed as crazy or killers but in real life none of them are like that

I would realy like to see other people with this and how they cope (not that i think its nice to see someone with this ofcourse but to compare). I am going to treatment for it in hopely a couple of months. I hope you can make this happen. Sorry for my crappy english.. tried my best üòÖ  Ur doing great! Kissesüíõ
Not schizophrenic but I could attest to the experience with hallucination. It was interesting to think about how the brain could make you feel like you sense something which is not there, and you try to comprehend what just "happened". One time, I was studying stressfully for the finals the next day. I've been through kinds of overnight studying, didn't sleep for 2 days once. That time I just realized that I was pushing my body and brain too far cause I just started hearing kids laughing in the middle of the night in my room, which freaked me out.Can't imagine how these peps deal with this considering they experience it most of the time in their lives.

My best friend is schizophrenic and is right now going through the process of first having to get her medication, and then go into a two year period where she will constantly be changing it until they get the right combination. Up until now, she has been able to live with for years, without it bothering her, but we think that with the combination of school beginning to be difficult, Covid taking over the world and just general stress, she now has to go on medication.  What I really want to say, after saying all of this, is thank you, for covering this topic. I always try and learn as much as I can about this condition, just so I can make things easier for her, because sometimes she can't even put to words what it is like to be schizophrenic, and having content like this, where multiple people describe it, makes it easier to get a bigger picture of it. Thank you for this, Anthony. And thank you to the guests. They are very Brave. Even though we got a long way on many aspects, it's still very much taboo to talk about. Suffering for years myself on the spectrum, and currently kicking the anti-psychotic medicine after 6+ on abilify. I Work together with a skilled doctor in the process, and it's kind of amazing to do in many ways. The most noticible change, is that i FEEL things again. Emotionally. Looking back on the years on meds, i realize how much i missed feeling things. It's overwhelming at times, but damn IT Geels good too.  Just wanna say, even though things look hopeless and dark, you CAN return. You probably wont be the next Superman, but you are a special kind of human anyway. You are important to other people, no matter what you may think. I really, really was convinced i was a lost cause, but the road back is there, if you happen to find it :) IT takes time, though. One thing i learned, that really stuck with me, is that it takes time, patience and a Lot of Hope. Hard work, too. But you CAN. And you WILL! I have hallucinations, I hear things, and I dissociate I‚Äôm also very paranoid. My hallucinations started when I was around 10 (I‚Äôm 15 now). These people are strong!

I had a months-long delusion that the world was not real. Likely not schizophrenia, I've not been diagnosed, but it lasted almost a year and was horrible. My mother would be sitting right next to me and I had to keep asking her, "Are you there?" Tapping her shoulder nonstop for confirmation. Going to sleep was the worst because when I closed my eyes, there was no input telling me there was a world around me. I was pretty much numb to any other input, like touch and noise. If I couldn't see the world, I didn't exist and I started falling away from everything. I found that a useful coping mechanism was to hold a solid object and focus on feeling it as I fell asleep. The more detailed/interactive, the better. It was really nice to hear these peoples' coping mechanisms for similar problems, like Kody and his camera trick. These delusions and paranoia are so, so scary.

I have a cousin that is 4 years younger than me. When he was like 15 and I was 19 he started experimenting with drugs and developed it. Growing up I felt sad because he was good one day and the next he was totally different. A therapist I spoke to told me that he was going to get it but the drugs just made it come sooner. He would tell us he was going to go to court and sue the government for a new head, new arms... and to call him blue eyes (he had brown eyes) . These ppl in the video talk normal, my cousin seemed lost, his eyes were lost. He ended up being deported at 18 because he was here with a passport and he ended up snapping and beating my uncle which would take care of him. He is now in a hospital/living residence. He is let out to go to the Dr or if my uncle wants to take him out for Lunch. I haven‚Äôt talked to him in a long time.. what used to be funny with the comments he would make suddenly got scary because he‚Äôs one of those violent snap at any moment patients. It must be so scary to see and hear things that aren‚Äôt there. Like how can they distinguish real life from not real life.

It's also worth mentioning that people with mental illness or disorders are far more likely to be victims of crimes rather than commiters of crime. Like they commit somewhere around 4-5% of all shootings, but at the same time somewhere around 30% of people with mental illness will be a victim. I'm currently writing a paper about mental illness and in my research I read a lot about how media over-represents people with mental illness such as schizophrenia as violent or dangerous when that is truly not the case. She‚Äôs so right we need to teach kids about mental health. When I first experienced OCD I enough it was god punishing me for Benny bad, and then I thought it was schizophrenia bc that word didn‚Äôt mean anything more to me then a name for mental illness. It wasn‚Äôt until someone on tv talked about OCD that I realized what was going on with me. It was a relief. I also dated a guy with schizophrenia. Sometimes it was sweet when he would talk to the bird outside the window. She‚Äôd tell him about her babies and he‚Äôd  worry for her. It was harder when he heard ‚Äúme‚Äù flirting with his roommate. I‚Äôd be making him dinner and he‚Äôd come in furious I was cheating on him. I also lived with two women with schizophrenia after a nervous breakdown. I was in a residential rehab and bc of my nurturing nature they put me with these women who had two very different forms of schizophrenia. One, she was also mentally disabled and would see Superman and ducks as well as black lines. The other had a NOS form and she had everything. She saw and heard things, delusions, she felt things. She‚Äôd tell me I was her daughter and she could tell bc I had the same Martian head protrusions she had. Or that the man on the toothpaste commercial was her son and she‚Äôd hook us up. She‚Äôd make movies part of her life and tell me about her adventures on witch mountain. She was very interesting. But I once met a woman with schizophrenia who was tormented. She was heavily scarred from setting herself on fire to escape the voices. I once heard her scream the most despairing scream I‚Äôd ever heard as she was tormented by voices. I‚Äôd struggled with debilitating OCD, depression, anxiety and addiction but I felt incredibly grateful I didn‚Äôt have schizophrenia. I‚Äôve had dissociative episodes and I‚Äôve learned to fear not having control over my mind. But what‚Äôs I‚Äôve experienced is nothing compared to what some ppl have to deal with. The mind is fascinating but also terrifying.

Ive had this diagnoses a few months ago and suffered for years since i started talking from being a toddler, and my parents tried getting me help back then, it was said to be imaginary friends until it got worse and worse until now. I went back to get help and the place where i live, they dont help at all. They put me in for finding ways to cure my anxiety instead of helping with voices and seeing, so i went back again and they dropped me and wont help me until im bad in THAT moment. I really dont get it, and i dont know how to get help anymore i really tried. They diagnosed me and left me and now my boyfriend tries to get me through things that happen but like the person said its the ‚Äúit will be okay‚Äù type things they help and dont its frustrating in a way. Im glad hes there for me though. For a LONG time i thought i was in contact with ghosts and demons and that i had powers. I go into psychosis and i feel invincible and that i can do anything and then sometimes i just feel like im in a dream and i have to hurt my self to get out of it or that i can kill myself and ill come back like a game. For a period of about a year and a couple of months I would hallucinate spiders and hands, it was during a time when I was stressed out by school, and my home life due to my parents separating. It always happened at night and I would dose off and then be jolted awake by seeing these big spiders over my face or I would see a hand reaching out of my face, it was such a weird and scary time and at first I couldnt tell if the spiders were real or not eventually my mother, siblings and I moved into a new home away from my father and ever since then I havent had those hallucinations.

Dear Anthony,  first of all: Thank you so much for this video... I hope nobody minds me sharing my own story, but please only read this if you feel stable enough. Please take care.  I have several mental illnesses, including schizoaffective disorder (schizophrenia with depression). I actually remember I was diagnosed when I was twenty, after a really, really rough time for my family and me. I had two psychotic episodes in total (one when I was twenty, one when I was almost twenty-two...). When I was twenty, my family was about to lose their home, we had no money, and we didn't have anywhere to go at first, I had just found out about the suicide of a friend of mine (and fallen for the delusional thought of her still being alive), and I couldn't sleep at all for several days. I then ended up in the hospital after I attempted to take my own life; the voices even told me what exactly I should do, where I could find what I'd need, and so on. I heard all the time how the voices wanted to harm me... And I hallucinated a sharp object floating above me, and felt it each time it went down to injure me. When I was in hospital, I heard all the time they wanted to poison me there, and I should rescue others from this. I was ready to, but I felt powerless.  The second psychotic episode started after I decided impulsively to stop taking my medication altogether, after I was insulted by my then-psychiatrist (I asked about ways to deal with anxiety (I have climacophobia and it was even worse back then than it is now...), and she basically told my mum (Who was in the room with me back then), "Can you now SEE what kind of stupid s*** I have to deal with every day?!" and then the psychiatrist turned to me, saying, "If your voices force you not to go downstairs or upstairs, that is none of my business!!" =_= I later on met people experiencing really awful stuff with this psychiatrist, too. I just felt back then like, you know, I am not just somebody who has heard voices. I also can experience other stuff. In the second hospital stay, I was told I most likely inherited my disorder from my biological father, who was extremely abusive towards us, as in, his then-family. That also hurt, because I compared myself to him, and I never treated anybody as he did in our direction... He also broke off contact beforehand, and we still don't talk; I know I have half-siblings but I never got to meet them... They also didn't tell us about the passing of my grandparents.  But back to this. In hospital, I experienced a different time "flow" so to say. I felt like everything was passing extremely quickly. :( Also, whenever I closed my eyes, I saw a doctor standing infront of my bed with a chainsaw, grinning in my direction.  I learned the hard way that medication is really important - at least for me. I reduced the dose over time, with the help of the doctors I was at after this psychiatrist back then. But I cannot get off them. It is way too dangerous, I learned. I need to pay attention to my sleep patterns, and not let things get too stressful. I haven't hallucinated in a while (the last time was when I was twenty-two, now I am thirty-six years old), and I still oftentimes doubt the diagnosis, but maybe mainly because back then the comparison with my biological father hurt so much.  I was also told in the hospital by a doctor back then, that therapy wouldn't work for my disorder, and boy, how wrong that was! Really. It can definitely help put things into perspective, and I definitely recommend therapy if you feel like this could help :). As I said, there are other problems I also deal with (Borderline & Avoidant Personality Disorder, PTSD, and an eating disorder).  I hope this all makes sense somehow, as I really struggle with keeping things coherent. If you guys have any questions, feel free to just ask.  Much love from my side (also to the people who were interviewed and everybody who deals with mental illness in whatever way)!
I was diagnosed with Schizoaffective Bipolar Type, along with a few other disorders back in December of 2019. I had struggled with these issues for a long time and have always been mistreated and misdiagnosed. The difference between the voices I hear compared to others is I actually have internal voices, except they are different from my thoughts. They have their own voices and are similar to an intrusive thought where they come out of no where and can‚Äôt be controlled. I have heard external noises before too though. During my psychotic breaks I tend to not be able to tell whether it‚Äôs internal or external, because I get so delusional.  When they brought up Mental Health and how people should be able to talk about it, I bursted into tears. Recently there was a suicide at my school, and i‚Äôve been working with a group in my school called Project ETS (ETS = End The Stigma) because the reason why people are so afraid to talk about mental health is because of the stigma they face. I‚Äôve been saying these kinds of things a lot recently and have for a while and to see someone else say the exact same thing is touching. Things need to change, and Mental Health should be treated the same way as Physical Health by society in the way that it‚Äôs still an illness and just as valid.
who els would love to see a video about adhd or bipolar disorder?
**an important message for the folks who run this channel**  IK y‚Äôall probably won‚Äôt read this, but I thought I‚Äôd still ask if you could either give warnings or just straight up remove footage of things like spiders and other common phobias. Obviously not everyone is afraid of spiders (although it is the most common phobia) but for those of us that are, it could and very much did trigger a panic attack‚Äîthis goes for other phobias as well. Thanks for hearing me out, and have a wonderful day!  Padildo No.165514, D-RgK

My Uncle was diagnosed with schizophrenia when he was only 20 years old. He suffers greatly on a daily basis, with Judgmental eyes watching and cruel words whispered. He is currently on his medication, which is good because he feels as if they help him. So much so that sometimes he feels ‚Äúcured‚Äù like he doesn‚Äôt need to take them anymore. Only every time that happens he ends up having an episode, leading him to lose another job and an apartment making him homeless... I will never know what it‚Äôs like to have this illness. But I do know what it feels like to watch a loved one suffer from it. He is often frightened by what he sees/hears...  it‚Äôs painful to watch.. because all I want to do is protect him from what‚Äôs scaring him but how can I when I can‚Äôt see it?  I‚Äôll sit with him for hours in the closet (he feels safe in there) bring him food, water, anything he needs until he takes his medication again. I‚Äôll defend him from strangers in public when they catch him talking to things that cannot be seen and saying things that rarely make sense. But behind all of this, my uncle is a loving man. Although he has had many jobs, I know that in his heart he is truly an artist. I honestly believe that when he plays his guitar he is telling me the things that have no words...

im also schizophrenic and a mother of 4, i suffer from auditory halucinations and most of the time it is always threatining to hurt my children and most of it starts once i sit down to relax, take a bath and the worst is when i try to lay down to go to bed. it used to keep me up for weeks until they finally figured out what was going on with me. i was already a mother at this time so it was really terrifying and i told them ive never heard people outside my window or outside my bedroom door before... when it first started i got so scared i had all of my kids and i and my husband all sleep in the same bed so that i knew they wouldnt be alone... luckily they were to young to remmember if i didnt find out and start finding ways to manage i could have really messed up their childhood.. ive gotten really good at ignoring these things now, but sometimes its all i can focus on while watching a movie my husband will laugh and look at me and he always can read my face, so i started calling them episodes the really bad ones i cant ignore because i just have to go out there and check... sometimes a few times before i finally just put up cameras everywhere now when i hear things i can pretend like nothing is happening and just see if it is there on camera. if i ever develop visual... i think ill be in alot of trouble

Hello
I haven't even started watching yet to write this and say I'm excited to see this for the fact that my mother and uncle have suffered from this illness all of my life. It's been a huge mark on my family and something we've struggled to understand. I'm grateful for today's medicine and that it allows people to live normal lives. Growing up, my biggest fear was and still is that myself or children/nieces will develop this disease. I've spent the majority of my adult life trying to research and understand but also learn how to help my mother live the best life she can. It's messed up how people of past generations have not been able to have the same treatment that we do now. There's definitely a spectrum of schizophrenia, not everyone has the same.
